div.p: A CATECHISME OR, The Grounds and Principles of Christian Religion, set forth by way of Question and Answer.
Wherein the summe of the Doctrine of Religion is comprised, familiarly opened, and clearly confirmed from the Holy Scriptures.
By RICHARD MATHER, Teacher to the Church at Dorchester in New England.

q.hi: Hold fast the form of sound words which thou hast heard of me in faith and love, which is in Christ Iesus.
When for the time ye ought to be Teachers, ye have need that one teach you again the first principles of the Oracles of God, and are become such as have need of Milke, and not of strong meat.

div.p: LONDON, Printed for Iohn Rothwell, and are to be sold at his shop at the signe of the Sunne and Fountaine in PauLs Church-yard neer the little North-gate. 1650.

div.head: TO THE CHRISTIAN READER.
div.p:
THe publique Catechizing of Children by way of familiar Dialogue in short and plaine Questions & Answers, though it be scrupled by some, as if it wanted Scripture warrant: yet such as acknowledge children to be members of Christs Kingdome and Church, (as all but Antipaedobaptists doe) Mar. 10. 14. they cannot deny, that (being members of Christs house) the Stewards of his house must (in faithfulnesse to Christ, and them) dispence a portion of Spirituall food to them in due season, Luke 12. 42. And evident it is by daily experience
that long Discourses (Sermon-wise) runne over Childrens heads (like water over a Mill, that grinds no meale at all) and passe their capacity. No way of instruction is so proper for them, as that which the Prophet describeth as most suitable to the understanding of children, line upon line, here a little and there a little (Isai 28. 9, 10.) which can no way so conveniently be dispensed, as in briefe and familiar questions and answers put into their mouthes.

But as this way of short and familiar catechizing is the fittest portion of young childrens bread: so there is a larger Doctrine of Catechisme, containing the whole body of Divinity, which being solidly compacted together, and evidently confirmed from Scripture light, and familiarly delivered to the apprehensions of Gods people, it will be a seasonable portion for children of riper age: not only for their further building up in the faith and obedience of the doctrine of the Gospel: but also for their establishment in the truth, that
they be not pluckt away with the error of the wicked. Hence Luther had his major as well as his minor Catechismus: and Beza his larger confession of the Faith as well as his shorter. Yea the Apostle Paul (whose example was now precedentiall, as being indeed Authenticall and binding to imitation) he committed to Timothy a platform of sound and wholsome words, in Faith and love: which he commanded and charged him, not onely to hold fast himself, 2 Tim. 1. 13. but likewise to commit the same to faithfull men, who might be able to teach others also, 2 Tim. 2. 2. This charge, as it then was (and alwaies will be) weighty, and seasonable: So never more important and necessary, then in this capritious and fastidious age, when men will nor suffer wholsome doctrine, but having itching eares and wits, doe turn away their hearts from the truth, and are given up to such empty and windy notions, wherein it is hard to judge whether Arrogancy or ignorance be the more predominent:
arrogance of higher attainements in Christ, or ignorance of the true Christ, and of life in him.

Now for casting in some helpe, (by the grace of Christ) to prevent the spreading of such a gangrene of vanity and apostacy; and to establish the people of God in the truth of the Doctrine which is according to godlinesse: Our reverend brother (according to the precious Talent of wisdom, and found judgement given unto him, &c. out of his faithfull love to the flock of Christ) he hath compiled this ensuing platform of wholsome Doctrine, in way of a larger Catechisme: wherein you shall finde the summe of the Doctrine of Christian Religion, with pithy solidity and orderly dexterity digested together; and with clear evidence of truth confirmed from the holy Scriptures: and both with such familiar plainnesse of savory language, as (by the blessing of Christ) the simple-honest-hearted Reader may be informed and established in the highest truths, and the most
intelligent may be refreshed and comforted, in revising and recounting the treasures of wisdome and knowledge which they have received and embraced, and the grounds upon which they have believed; and all may be led on in the constant profession and practice of the faith and love which is in Christ Jesus.
So we commend this ensuing Treatise to the diligent perusall of the Christian Reader; and both it and thee to the rich blessing of the grace of Christ, and rest

closer.signed: Thine to serve in the faith and love of the Gospel, JOHN COTTON. JOHN WILSON.

div.head: THE Grounds and Principles of Christian Religion.
CHAP. I. Of Catechizing as an Introduction to that which followeth.
Quest. WHat is Catechizing?
div.p: Ans. An instructing of the people in the grounds, or principles, or fundamentall points of Religion.

div.head: Q. How are these Catechisticall, and fundamentall points called in the holy Scripture?
div.p: A. They are called thge foundation Heb. 6. 2., the first principles of the Oracles of God Heb. 5. 12., the beginning of the doctrine of Christ, Heb. 6. 1. the entrance into Gods word, Ps. 119. 130. milke for babes, Heb. 5. 12, 13. 1 Cor. 3. 1, 2. and the form of wholsom words 2 Tim. 1. 13..

div.head: Q. How may the warrantablenesse of this kind of teaching appeare?
div.p: A. Both by expresse testimony of Scripture Heb. 5. 12, 23. & 6. 1, 2. 1 Cor. 3. 1, 2., and because Catechising is nothing else but the drawing of the doctrine of Religion into briefe summes; and this hath plentifull warrant in the word Eccles. 12. 13. Deut. 4. 13. Matth. 22. 37, 38, 39, 40. 2 Tim. 1. 13. Mat. 6. 9..

div.head: Q. What need is there of this kind of teaching?
div.p: A. The doctrine of Catechisme being milke for babes, and the laying of the foundation, there cannot but be great need thereof; for all men know the foundation must be layd afore there can be any building; and babes must have milke afore they be fed with stronger meat.

div.head: Q. What is the benefit of catechising?
div.p: A. It is a means of well grounded knowledge, Psa. 119. 130. and of profiting by Sermons; the want whereof being an hinderance that men cannot profit by other higher points of doctrine Heb. 5. 12, 13..

div.head: Q. What else may be the benefit thereof?
div.p: A. It is a means to prevent apostasie Prov. 22. 6. and the infection of errour, which they that are ignorant and unstable are apt to be seduced withall 2 Pet. 2. 14. & 3. 16..

div.head: Q. Doe you then think that the doctrine of catechisme is wholsome and usefull to the soules of Gods people?
div.p:
A. As common and ordinary meats are most wholsome to the body, more then curious and
dainty dishes: so the doctrine of Catechisme is specially wholsome to the soule, and therefore is expresly called the form of wholsome words 2 Tim. 1. 13..

div.head: Q. How should the doctrine of catechisme be handled?
div.p: A. Briefly, many things being contracted into narrow summes, for the helping of memory Eccles. 12. 13. Heb. 8. 1. Deut. 4. 13. Matth. 22. 40. & 6 9, 10. &c. , and yet plainly Heb. 5. 12. 1 Cor. 3. 2. Mar. 4. 33. 1 Cor. 14. 19., as may be for the understanding of the simple.

div.head: Q. What are we to think of that usuall way of catechizing by questions and answers?
div.p: A. This way of teaching hath plentifull warrant in the Scriptures Luke 2. 47. Act. 2. 38. 1 Pet. 3. 15., and is suitable to the notation, and signifitation of the word Catechising, which is taken from that returne or answer which is given in an Eccho

div.head: Q. Who are to be catechised?
div.p: A. All that have need thereof, as being not well instructed in these points; and therefore little children Prov. 22. 6. Deut. 4 9, 10. Psa. 78. 5, 6. & 34. 11. Mat. 21. 15, 16. Luke 2. 47. Eph. 6. 4. are to be catechised as soon as they shall be able to learn, and others also that are ignorant Heb. 5. 12, 13 1 Cor. 3. 1, 2. or children in understanding.

div.head: Q. But is it not a shame for persons of yeers to be catechised?
div.p: A. It is a shame, and justly reproveable as a sinne, when persons grown to yeeres are so ignorant as to have need to be catechised. Heb. 5. 5. 12, 13. 1 Cor. 15. 34.

div.head: Q. But how if they be not willing to be catechised?
div.p: A. It is much more a sinne and shame, if being ignorant they refuse to have their ignorance holpen by being instructed, Psal. 58. 5. Prov. 17, 22. & 13. 18. & 15. 32.

div.head: Q. But is it not indeed a reproach and shame unto a man to be catechised?
div.p: A. It is so farre from being a shame, that indeed it is the duty of all to be willing to learn Prov. 4 13. & 8. 32, 33. & 23 12, 23., and therefore not a shame unto any; but the commendation of every one that is so willing Prov. 1. 5. & 10. 17. & 12. 1. Iob 34. 32. Act. 18. 26.

div.head: CHAP. 2. Of the holy Scriptures.

Q. YOu have shewed that to be instructed in the principles of Religion, is both warrantable, needfull, and profitable; tell likewise whence we must take direction for attaining wel-grounded knowledge in these principles, and all other points of Religion?
div.p: A. Out of those sacred books or writings, which are called the holy Scriptures.

div.head: Q. Hath the word and will of God alwaies been set down in writing?
div.p:
A. No: Moses was the first Penman of holy
Scripture, who Iived not till above two thousand yeeres after the creation.

div.head: Q. How was the will of God made known to his people in those times afore the Scriptures were written?
div.p: A. By divers and sundry meanes Heb. 1. 1., as by visions Num. 12. 6, 8., by dreames Iob 33. 14, 15. Gen. 40. 8., by visible signes Gen. 32. 24. Exod. 13. 21., and by audible voyce Gen. 22. 15. Exod. 20. 2..

div.head: Q. Why did God afterward cause his will to be set down in writing?
div.p: A. That it might be the better preserved Is. 30. 8., that it might be conveyed to posterity Deut. 31. 9. Psa. 102. 18, and that it might be an infallible standard to try all doctrines by Isa. 8. 20. 2 Pet. 1. 19..

div.head: Q. What are the books of holy Scriptures?
div.p: A. The bookes of the Old Testament 2 Cor. 3. 14. as they are expressed in our Bibles.

div.head: Q. VVhy are these writings called holy?
div.p: A. They are called holy 2 Tim. 3. 15. Rom. 1. 2. because they have an holy Authour, which is God Act. 1. 16. & 4. 25., were written by Pen-men who were holy men Luke 13. 28. 2 Pet. 1. 21., and because the doctrine which is conteined in them is all for the promoting of holinesse in us Tit. 1. 1. 1 Tim. 6. 3. 2 Tim. 3. 17..

div.head: Q. How may it he proved that these Bookes are indeed the word of God?
div.p: A. Because it is said they were given by inspiration of God 2 Tim. 3. 16. p 2 Pet. 1. 21., and that the Penmen of them spake as they were moved, or acted by the holy Ghost p.

div.head: Q. How elseb
div.p: A. By the wonderfull efficacy of them, as in other things, so in this, that they enter into the heart, for conviction, and humiliation Heb. 4. 12. 1 Cor. 14. 25. 2 Cor. 10. 4, 5., and are mighty through God to convert and comfort the soule Psal. 19. 8, &c. & 119 93, 103..

div.head: Q. How else may it be proved that the Scriptures are the word of God?
div.p: A. Because they must either be the word of God, and have him for the Author of them, or else some creature must be the author of them; which latter is not possible.

div.head: Q. It is true indeed, if no creature be the author of them, then God the creator must; but why may not some creature be their author?
div.p: A. A good creature, Angel or man, could never be so impious, presumptuous, and blasphemous, as to father his own doings upon God, falsly making him the Author of them; and a wicked creature would never shew such care and zeale for the glory of God, such dislike and detestation of all kind of sinne, as the book of the Scriptures doth.

div.head: Q. What particular uses are the Scriptures profitable for?
div.p: A. For the teaching of true doctrine, and convincing the contrary, for correction or reformation of errors in life, and for instructing unto good duties, 2 Tim. 3. 16.

div.head: Q. Are the Scriptures a compleat and sufficient rule of direction for all points of faith and life?
div.p: A. Yea; for they were written for that very end, that we might believe on Christ Jesus, and believing have eternall life through his name Iohn 20. 31.: and they are able to make one wise unto salvation through the faith which is in Christ Jesus 2 Tim. 3. 15.

div.head: Q. How else may this sufficiency and perfection of the Scriptures appeare?
div.p: A. It may appeare also by this, in that by the Scriptures, the man of God, who needs more abilities then other men, may be perfect, and throughly furnished unto all good works 2 Tim. 3. 17.; and because it is a cursed thing to adde any thing thereto Gal. 1. 8, 9. Revel. 22. 18..

div.head: Q. Doth the knowledge of the Scriptures belong unto all, or onely to the Learned?
div.p:
A. Not onely Magistrates Deut. 17. 18, 19. Iosh. 1. 8. and Ministers 2 Tim 3. 17. 1 Tim. 4. 13., but every housholder Deut. 6. 7., yea simple people Ps. 19. 7. & Prov. 1. 4.; yea women Acts 18. 26. 2 Ioh. 1., young men Psa. 119. 9., and children 2 Tim. 3. 15, ought to be acquainted with the Scriptures; and therefore the knowledge of them doth belong unto
all sorts of people.

div.head: CHAP. 3. Of God.
Q. YOu have shewed that the meanes of well grounded knowledge is the holy Scripture; tell me now what it is that the Scriptures doe especially teach us?
div.p: A. They teach us especially the saving knowledge of God, and of Jesus Christ. Iohn 17. 3. Col. 2. 2, 3.

div.head: Q. How may it be proved that there is a God?
div.p: A. The Scriptures doe abundantly, and plainly testifie it Exod. 20. 3. Isa. 42. 8. Heb. 11. 5. Iohn 17. 3.; and the creation of the world doth shew it Rom. 1. 20. Psal. 9. 1. Iob 12. 7, 8, &c. .

div.head: Q. How doth the creation of the world shew that there is a God?
div.p: A. Even as a faire and sumptuous building doth shew that some body was the maker of it, so this great world doth shew there was a maker of it which is God. Heb. 3. 4.

div.head: Q. But why might not the world be without beginning and have its being of it selfe?
div.p: A. Because then the world should be God, for that which hath its being of its self, and is without beginning, is God.

div.head: Q. How else may it be proved that there is a God?
div.p: A. The succession of day, and night, and other seasons with the sustentation, and ordering of the Creatures and the motions of them, doth plainly witnesse that there is a God. Psal. 19. 2. 3. Acts. 14. 17. Amos. 4 13. & 5. 8.

div.head: Q. How may this be expressed in some familiar comparison.
div.p: A. When a ship is seene at Sea with her Sayles spread, and her passage rightly guided unto the harbour, it appeareth thereby, that there were men that guided the same; for if there were no men, there would never be any ships upon the Sea: Even so the preservation of the great ship of the world, and the guidance of its motions, doth evidently shew, that there is a God by whom the same is preserved, and guided.

div.head: Q. What else may be a further proofe that there is a God?
div.p: A. That there is a God is manifestly declared by the strange and wonderfull plagues and judgments, that sometimes are inflicted upon notorious sinners upon earth. Exod. 8. 19. & 9. 16. Psal. 9. 16. & 58. 10. 11: & 79 10.

div.head: Q. What may be thought of those accusations, and terrors of conscience, that sometimes are found in men, upon the committing of haynous sins, though knowne to no man living, but to the sinner himselfe?
div.p: A. This also is another testimony that there is a God, before whose judgment seate a man must answer for his deedes; for otherwise why should a man be afraid where no feare is? Rom. 2. 15. Isa. 33. 14. Psal. 14. 5. & 53. 5.

div.head: Q. How many Gods are there?
Q. Why may there not be more Gods then one?
div.p: A. Because that is contrary to the nature of God which is to be infinite, and everlasting, that is the first, and the last; now there cannot be many infinites, nor many firsts and lasts, but one only.

div.head: Q. How else doth the nature of God shew that there can be no more but one God?
div.p: A. It is the nature of God to have his being of himselfe, and so give being to whatsoever else hath being; for so much is signified by the word Iehovah. Exod. 3. 14. & 6. 3. & 15. 3.

div.head: Q. And how doth this prove that there can be no more but one God?
div.p: A. Because if there were many Gods, then either they must one give being to the other, or each one have his being of himself, both which are utterly impossible.

div.head: Q. Why might not one of them give being to the other?
div.p: A. Because then that other could not bee God, as not having his being of himselfe.

div.head: Q. And why might they not be many Gods, each one having his God-head of himselfe?
div.p: A. Because then none of them could be God, as not giving being to all others which had being.

div.head: Q. Though there be but one God, yet is there not more persons, or subsistences in the Godhead then one?
div.p: A. Yes; the Scriptures doe apparently witnesse that in the unity of the divine essence, there is a plurality of the divine persons. Gen. 1. 26. & 3. 22. & 11. 7. Isai. 6. 8. & 41. 22, 23.

div.head: Q. How many are the Persons in the Godhead?
div.p: A. They are three, the Father, the Son, and the Holy-Ghost, Math. 3. 16, 17. & 28. 19. Ioh. 14. 16, 17. & 15. 26. 2 Cor. 13, 14. Gal. 4. 6. 1 Ioh. 5. 7.

div.head: Q. Whether are these three, the Father, the Son, and the Holy-Ghost severall, and distinct Persons, or onely severall names, and titles of one, and the same person.
Q. What are the personall properties, whereby each is distinguished from other?
div.p: A. The property of the Father is to beget the Son Ps. 2. 7. Ioh. 3. 16., the property of the Son to be begotten of the Father Ioh. 1. 18. Heb. 1. 13., the property of the Holy Ghost to proceed from the Father and the Son Ioh. 15. 16., who is therefore called the spirit of the Father Matth. 10. 20., and of the Son Gal. 4. 6. Rom. 8. 9.,

div.head: Q. Are every one of these persons God?
div.p: A. Yea: Of the Father there is lesse question, and the Scriptures doe witnesse that the Son is God Col. 29. Isa. 9. 9. Ioh. 1. 1 Rom. 9. 5. Prov. 8. 22. &c. Ioh. 17. 5. Col. 1. 16., and also that the Holy Ghost is God Acts 5. 3. 4. & 28. 25. with Is. 6. 9. 1 Cor. 6. 19. with 2 Cor. 6. 16. Iob. 33. 4. 1 Cor. 2. 10.,

div.head: Q. You have shewed that there is a God, and and onely one God, and three persons; tell me now what God is?
div.p: A. God is so infinite, and incomprehensible, that no creature is able fully to comprehend or know him. Exod. 33. 20. 23. Iob. 26. 14. & 11. 7, 8, 9. 1 Tim. 6. 16.

div.head: Q. How then may we conceive of him?
div.p: A. As he hath revealed himselfe to us Deut. 29. 29., in his back parts Exod. 33. 23., which are his divine attributes Exod. 34. 6, 7., and by his workes Psal. 19. 1. & 8. 1. Iob. 36. 24. &c. & 37. 1. 2. &c. ,

div.head: Q. What are those Attributes or back parts of God?
div.p: A. Wisdome Iob. 12, 13. Rom. 11. 33. & 16. 27. Power, Gen. 17. 1. & 18. 14. Matth. 19. 26. Psal. 115. 3. Goodnesse Matth. 19. 17. Psal. 119. 68., Truth Psal. 108. 4. Rom. 3, 4. Tit. 1. 2., Justice Psal. 92. last. Zeph. 3. 5. Rom. 9. 14. Iob. 8. 3. & 34. 10. & 36. 23., Mercy Psal. 103. 11. Iam. 5. 11., and the like, in all which he is infinite 1 Kings 8. 27. Isa. 66. 1. Ier. 23. 24. Psal. 139. 7, &c. , and everlasting Ps. 90. 2. & 93, 3. & 102. 26, 27..

div.head: Q. What are the works of God?
div.p: A. They are three, Decree, Creation, and Providence.

div.head: CHAP. 4. Of Gods Decree.
Q. WHat is Gods Decree?
div.p: A. That whereby he hath before determined and decreed with himselfe whatsoever shall come to passe.

div.head: Q. Doe you say that Gods decree reacheth to all things whatsoever cometh to passe in time?
div.p: A. Yea all things whatsoever have been, are, or that shall be hereafter, were before decreed, and determined by God. Eph. 1. 11. Act. 15. 18.

div.head: Q. What are some of the principall things that are so decreed?
div.p: A. Things that are most casuall Exod. 21. 13. Prov. 16. 33. things that are most freely done by the creature, Prov. 21. 1. Ps. 33. 15. and things wherein the creature commits abundance of sin Act. 2. 28. & 4. 28.,

div.head: Q. What else?
div.p: A. Such things as seeme small and little Matth. 20. 29. 30., are also great, and speciall events.

div.head: Q. What are some of those great and speciall events that are decreed by the Lord?
div.p: A. The comming and death of Christ, and all the workes of his mediatorship 1 Pet 1. 20. Rev. 13. 18., the salvation of the Godly Ephes. 1. 4. 2 Tim. 1. 9. 1 Thes. 5 9., the damnation of the wicked Iud. 4. Rom. 9. 22., the day of every mans particular death Iob. 14. 5. 14. and the day of the generall judgement Act. 17. 31.,

div.head: Q. When were all these things decreed by God?
div.p: A. Before the world was created, even from everlasting, 1 Cor. 2. 7. Eph. 1. 4. & 3. 11. 1 Pet. 1. 20. 2 Tim. 1. 9.

div.head: Q. What was the cause of Gods decrees?
div.p: A. The cause that moved him to decree was nothing foreseene in the creature, but his own will, and good pleasure. Rom. 9. 11. 18. Matth. 11. 25. 26.

p.hi: But sith some are appointed by the decree of God to damnation, if his will be the cause of that decree, how is that just?

div.p: Yea, it is most just and righteous notwitstanding, Rom. 13, 14.

div.head: Q. How may that appeare.
div.p:
A. Because the will of God is the rule of all righteousnesse Eph. 1. 11. Psal. 115. 3. & 135. 6., and because the Lord hath absolute
power over all creatures, as the Potter hath power over his clay Rom. 9. 19, 20..

div.head: Q How else may the justice of the Lord in his decrees appeare?
div.p: A. Because what ever be the Lords decree, there is no man actually condemned till he be first defiled with sinne. Rom. 3. 9, 19. & 2. 6, 9. Genes. 4. 7.

div.head: Q. VVhether is the decree of God certaine, and immutable, or such as may be changed, and not take effect?
div.p: A. It is altogether unchangeable, and shall surely be accomplished, Psal. 33. 11. & 135. 6. Isa. 46. 10. & 14. 27. Rom. 9. 11.

div.head: Q. If the decree of God be unchangeable, then what needs man to be carefull in the use of means for his owne good?
div.p: A. Yes, the meanes must be used notwithstanding God decree; and that partly because the meanes are appointed, and decreed of God as well as the end Acts 27. 24. Eph. 1. 4. 2 Thes. 2. 13. Deut. 29. 29.; and partly because the revealed will and command of God is our rule, and not his secret decree n.

div.head: Q. Do you think then that Gods decree doth not excuse men from blame in the sinnes which they do commit.
div.p:
A. It doth not excuse them at all Luk. 22. 22. Mat. 18. 7., and the reason is because the decree of God infuseth no
Corruption into the hearts of men, not constraineth them to sinne against their will, but they sinne most freely, and willing of their own accord.

div.head: Q Is the decree of God secret within himselfe or revealed and made knowne?
div.p: A. It is secret within himselfe, till himselfe do reveale it, and therefore further then so it is not to be searched into. Rom. 11. 33. 34 1 Cor. 2 • 16. Deut. 29. 29.

div.head: Q. How doth God reveale his decree?
div.p: A. Partly by his word, wherein this doctrine is plainly, and plentifully taught Rom. 9. 11, &c. Eph. 1. 4, 5, 11. Math. 25. 34, 41, Luk. 10 20., and partly by the execution and accomplishment of things in time.

div.head: Q. How doth the execution or accomplishment of things reveale Gods decree?
div.p: A. Yea very clearely, because nothing was decreed but he executes the same in time; and whatsoever is brought to passe in time was determined and decreed afore: Ephes. 1. 11. Psal. 135. 6. Isa. 46. 10.

div.head: Q. How many wayes may the decree of God be considered?
div.p: A. As respecting all the creatures in generall, or as it respects the reasonable Creatures, Angels and men, in speciall.

div.head: Q. What are the parts of Gods decree as it respecteth man?
div.p: A. Election and reprobation.

div.head: Q. What is Election?
div.p: A. It is the decree of God or his predestination Eph. 1. 5. 11. Rom. 8. 29. whereby of his owne free love Rom. 9. 3. Ier. 31. 3. and good pleasure Eph. 1. 5. Rom. 9. 15. 2 Tim. 1. 9. he hath from everlasting Eph. 1. 4. Ier. 31. 3. appointed and chosen some certaine men 2 Tim. 2. 19. Act. 13. 48. to the obtaining of grace Eph. 11. 5. Rom. 8. 29., and Salvation 1 Thes. 5. 9. Rom. 9. 23. by Christ Ephes. 1. 3, 4. Ioh. 17. 2., for the praise of his glorious grace Ephes. 1. 6. Rom. 9. 23.,

div.head: Q. And what is reprobation?
div.p: A. It is the decree of God wherby of his meere will and good pleasure Rom. 9. 11, 15, 18, 21. some certaine men Iude. 4. are not elected and ordained to life Mat. 7. 23. Rev. 13. 8. & 17. 8., but on the on the contrary are appointed to destruction or damnation Iude. 4. Rom. 9. 21, 22. to be inflicted upon them for their sinne Rom. 3. 9, 19., to the praise of Gods glorious justice 9. 17, 22.,

div.head: CHAP. 5. Of Creation.
Q. HAd this world a beginning by Creation, or was it from everlasting?
div.p:
A. The scripture in many places, and speci▪ in the first of Gen. doth declare that the World was not from everlasting, but had a beginning by the Lords creating of it, Heb. 11. 3. Reu. 4. 11.
Prov. 8. 22. &c. Ps. 90. 2. Eph. 1. 4.

div.head: Q. Who was it that created the world?
div.p: A. God that is without beginning, and hath his being of himselfe, he it was who gave beginning, and being to the world. Gen. 1. 1. Act. 17. 24. Isay. 40. 28. & 44. 24.

div.head: Q. Whether was this the worke of the Father, or of the Sonne, or of the Holyghost?
div.p: A. Of every person in the trinity; not of the father onely but also of the sonne Ioh. 1. 3. 10. Col. 1. 16., and of the Holyghost Iob 26. 13 and 33. 4..

div.head: Q. What are the things that are created?
div.p: A. All things without exception, that have a being, except God onely who did create them, Act. 4. 24. & 17. 24. & 14, 15. Gen. 2. 1. Rev. 4. 11.

div.head: Q. Doe you meane that the third heaven was also created by God?
div.p: A. Yes, for that heaven is said to be a city whose builder, & maker is God, Heb. 11. 10. 16.

div.head: Q. But what thinke you of the Angels, were they also created by God?
div.p: A. Angels are the cheife of those invisible things, those thrones and Dominions, Principalities, and powers, which are expressely mentioned to have been created by the Lord. Col. 1. 16.

div.head: Q. Wherewith did God make the world?
div.p:
A. Though men must have tooles, and instruments, and sometimes more hands then their
owne for the effecting of works; yet when the Lord made the world, with him it was not so.

div.head: Q. How then or wherewith did he make it?
div.p: A. He made it himselfe alone Isa. 44. 25. Iob. 9. 8., and without any other meanes but onely by his word Gen. 1. 3. psal. 33. 6. 9. and 148. 5. Heb. 11. 3..

div.head: Q Whereof or of what materials did he create the world?
div.p: A. Not of any praeexistent matter, but of nothing Heb. 11. 3. Rom. 4. 17.

div.head: Q. How do you meane when you say that all things are made of nothing? for the body of Adam was made of the dust of the ground, and fishes of the waters, and therefore it may seeme all things were not made of nothing.
div.p: A. I meane that some things were made of nothing without any matter at all, and that the first matter whereof other things were made, was not eternall, but was immediately created of nothing; and that that first matter was so in▪ disposed to be the things that were made of it, that no lesse a power was seene in making other things out of it, then in making that first matter, or the lumpe it selfe; as it was as great a worke to bring great whales out of the waters, as to bring forth the water out of nothing; and in these respects, all things may be said to be made of nothing.

div.head: Q. In what time was the world created?
div.p: A. Every particular thing quickly, and as it were in an instant Psal. 33. 9, and the whole in the space of six dayes Gen. 1. Exod 10 11..

div.head: Q. What was the worke of Each day?
div.p: A. The worke of the first day was Heaven, the darke and deepe lumpe of earth, and waters, and light.

div.head: Q. What of the second day?
div.p: A. The firmament which is called Heaven.

div.head: Q. What of the third day?
div.p: A. The gathering of the waters together, which is called Sea, the drying of the earth, and making it fruitfull.

div.head: Q. What of the three last dayes?
div.p: A. On the fourth day sun, moone, and starres, on the fifth day fish, and foule, on the sixt day beasts and creeping things, and man.

div.head: Q. When was the highest heaven, and Angels created?
div.p: A. Most likely on the first day, Gen. 1. 1. Iob. 38 7.

div.head: Q. Why was God sixe dayes in making the world?
div.p: A. Not because hee needed so much time, but that we might more distinctly consider of his workes.

div.head: Q. Why did God make the world?
div.p: A. Not because he needed it, for he is alsufficient in and of himselfe, not needing any thing, but giving into all life, and breath, and all things Act. 17. 25.

div.head: Q. Did he make it out of necessity of nature, ot because he could not choose?
div.p: A. No, for had he pleased, he might have made it sooner, or later, or not at all.

div.head: Q. Why then did he make it?
div.p: A. Because it so pleased him, Revel. 4. 11.

div.head: Q. For what end did God make the World?
div.p: A. For the declaration of his owne glory. Prov. 16. 4. Rom. 11. 36. Col. 1. 16.

div.head: Q. What was the state of all things by creation?
div.p: A. God looked upon all the worke which he had made, and behold it was very good. Gen. 1. 31.

div.head: CHAP. 6. Of Gods providence.
Q. WHat is the Providence of God?
div.p: A. That whereby God doth preserve, and governe, dispose, and order all creatures with all their actions.

div.head: A. What scriptures do shew that there is such a providence of God?
div.p: Q. Many, and namely these, Ioh. 5. 17. Eph. 1. 11. Act. 17. 25. 28. Lam. 3. 37: Eccles. 3. 1. 2 &c.

div.head: Q. How els may the same be proved?
div.p: A. Such is the wisedme, and knowledge of God, that nothing can come to passe, but he must needes know it, and such is his omnipotency, that what he absolutely would not have to be, he is able to hinder it, and therefore nothing falls out but he seeth it, and by his providence hath an hand therein.

div.head:
Q. What are the parts of Gods providence, or the
severall acts of it?
div.p: A. Preserving of the creatures Act. 17. 18. 1. Tim. 4. 10. Ps. 36. 6. and goverment of them Psal. 29. 10. & 103. 19..

div.head: Q. What need is there of the providence of God for the preservation of creatures?
div.p: A. Yes very much, aswell as of his power for the creating of them.

div.head: Q. How may that appeare?
div.p: A. Not onely because making, and preserving of the creatures, are Coupled together as acts of the same power Neh. 9. 6.. but also because otherwise the creatures could not continue in being, but would soon returne to nothing Ps. 104. 29..

div.head: Q. And why must the government of the creatures be also ascribed to God?
div.p: A. Partly because it would argue inperfection in God, if he should make creatures, and leave the government of them to others; and partly because the creatures would never certainly▪ attaine the ends for which they were created, if they were not governed by the same power by which they were created.

div.head: Q. VVhat are the things whereto the providence of God doth extend?
div.p: A. All things without exception of any. Rom. 11. 36 Eph. 1 11.

div.head: Q. VVhat are some sorts of them?
div.p:
All persons, and all living things, though never so meane Psal. 145. 15, 16. and 104. 21. & 147. 9. Luk. 12. 6., and all the very accidents, and
Circumstances of actions, as the times, and seasons of them Prov. 16. 1. 33. Ioh. 14. 5. Psal. 31. 16. Eph. 1. 10. Ioh. 8. 20. and the like.

div.head: Q. What kinde of actions of the Creatures are ordered by the providence of God?
div.p: A. All kinde of actions, whether they be great or small Dan. 4. 25, 32, Psa. 76. 12. Iob. 12. 17, 18, 19, 20. Ps. 135. 7. & 113. 7, 9. Mat. 10. 29. Prov. 16. 1. 1. King. 20. 23., whether they be of kindnesse, and favour unto men, or of judgement & correction Amos 3. 6. Isa. 45. 7. Lam. 3. 37, 38..

div.head: VVhat else?
div.p: A. Actions that are most contingent, and casuall Prov. 16. 1, 33. Exod. 21. 13. 1 King 22. 34., and actions wherein the creature is most sinfull, and wicked Ezek. 14. 9. Deut. 2. 30. Isa. 29, 9. 10. Gen. 45. 8. 2. Sam. 12. 11..

div.head: Q. How farre forth hath God an hand by his providence in the sinfull actions of creatures?
div.p: A. Partly by permitting sinne to enter, when he could easily hinder the same, if he pleased; and partly by disposing and ordering of it for good ends.

div.head: A. How doth God permit the entrance of sinne?
div.p:
A. Partly by leaving men to themselves, not bestowing upon them his grace, that might keep them from sinne Deut. 29. 3, 4, 2 Chron. 32. Act. 14. 16., and partly by letting Sathan loose upon them to be blinded, and mis-led by
his temptations 1. King. 22. 22, 23. 1 Sam. 16. 15. 16..

div.head: Q. How is this just that God should deny the assistance of his grace, and leave men to themselves, and the temptations of Sathan?
div.p: A Yes, it is very just, because he is debtor to none, but may bestow his grace where, and upon whom he pleaseth. Rom. 11. 35. Mat. 20. 15.

div.head: Q. VVhat else may be said for the cleering of Gods justice herein?
div.p: A. God being the Judge of the world may punish sinne with what punishment he seeth meete, and so by giving sinners up unto further sinne, Ps. 8 • . 11. 12. Rom. 1. 24, 25, 26. &c. 2 Thes 2. 11, 12.

div.head: Q VVhat may be some instance of Gods disposing and ordering of sinne for good ends?
div.p: A. The sinne of Joseph brethren when they sold him into Egypt, which God disposed, and ordered for the preserving of Iacob and his house in time of famine. Gen 45. 5. 7. & 50. 20.

div.head: Q VVhat else?
div.p: A. The sinne of Amnon, and Absolom which God disposed and ordered for the Correction, and Humiliation of David. 2 Sam. 12. 10. 11, 12.

div.head: Q. VVhat may be a third instance hereof?
div.p:
A. The great sinne, and wickednesse of them who put the Lord Jesus Christ to death, as fowle a fact as the sunne ever saw, and yet even this did
the Lord dispose, and order for the redemption and salvation of his elect, Act. 2. 23. & 4. 27, 28.

div.head: Q. But if God by his providence have a stroake in ordering of the sinnes of men, is not God himselfe then tainted with sinne?
div.p: A. No, by no meanes: for God cannot be tempted of evill Iam. 1. 13., neither doth any sin proceed from him 1. Ioh. 2. 18., but contrarily he is then holy, holy, holy, when he gives men up to be hardened in their sinnes Isa. 6. 3, 9. 10..

div.head: Q. VVhat else may be said for the further learning of this truth?
div.p: A. God is so far from being tainted hereby with the uncleannesse of sinne, that his wisdome and goodnesse doth hereby the more appear, in that he can worke good by evill instruments, and make even sinne it selfe to seeme to his glory.

div.head: Q But whether may not sinners then hereby have excuse for themselves, and lay the blame of their sin upon God?
div.p: A. If God did infuse corruption into the hearts of men, or incline them or command them to sins who else were unwilling so to doe, then there were more colour for this demand; but this cannot be affirmed with truth.

div.head: Q. VVhat then is truth in this case?
div.p:
A. God made man altogether righteous and upright Eccle. 7. 29,, and gives men an holy commandement
that prohibits all sinne Gen. 2. 17. Rom. 7. 12., and yet they sinne of their owne accord Eccles. 7. 29., and therefore their destruction (and so their sinne as cause thereof) is of themselves Hos. 13. 9..

div.head: Q. May not this be illustrated by some similitude, to shew how God may have an hand in the evill actions of men, and yet all the sinfulnesse of the action be wholly of the creature and not of God?
div.p: A. As he that spurs a lame horse, is the cause of his going, but not of his halting, which is from the beast himselfe; and as the sunne shining on a carcasse, or a dunghill, is the cause of the savour, but not of the stench which is from the carcasse it selfe; even so it is in this case.

div.head: Q. How or in what manner doth the providence of God put forth, and shew it selfe?
div.p: A. Most freely and as it pleaseth him Psal. 115. 3. and 135. 6., most commonly in the ordinary use of the means 2 King. 14. 27. Hos. 2. 21, 22. and sometimes it pleaseth him to work without meanes Deut. 9. 18. & 29. 5, 6. 1 King 19. 8, Isay. 37. 30..

div.head: Q. How else doth the providence of God put forth and shew itselfe?
div.p:
A. Sometimes by working great and mighty workes by weake meanes 1 Cor. 1. 26, 27. Iudg. 7. 2, 3. 2 Chron. 24. 24. 2 Sam. 14, 7. Amos 5. 9. Ier. 37. 10,, sometimes by disapppointing the best and the most probable meanes that they become ineffectuall, Ps. 78. 9, 10. Eccles. 9. 13. Hos. 4. 10. Ps. 127. 1, 2, 3.; and sometimes by working contrary to all meanes,
and the naturall course of things Iosh. 3. 15, 16. & 10. 13. & 2 King. 20. 10, 11. Dan. 3. 27. 2 King. 6. 6..

div.head: CHAP. 7. Of Angels.
Q. WHat are the Kindes of Gods providence?
div.p: A. It is either generall towards all Creatures, or specially towards some.

div.head: Q. What are those speciall creatures which the providence of God doth extend unto?
div.p: A. Angels and men.

div.head: Q. VVhat is the nature of Angels?
div.p: A. They are Spirits Ps. 104. 4. Heb. 1. 14. Luk. 24. 39. or spirituall substances, and therefore invisible that they cannot be seene with bodily eyes, no more then the wind that bloweth, or the soules of men, nor are they preserved by sleep and food, & raiment, as living bodyes are Mat. 22. 30.; and yet they are immortall, and cannot dye Luk. 20. 36..

div.head: Q. VVhat else are we to know concerning the nature of Angels?
div.p: A. That they are creatures of excellent strength Ps. 103. 20. 2 Pet. 2. 11., great acutenesse of understanding 2 Sam. 14. 20. mat. 18. 10., very swift and speedy in their motion Isa. 6. 2. Ezek. 1. 6. Dan. 9. 21., and by creation very pure, and holy Gen. 1. 31. Luk. 9. 26..

div.head: Q. What is the number of Angels?
div.p: A. Though they be not infinite, yet their number is very great, and to us they are innumerable. Dan. 7. 10. Ps. 68. 17. Mat. 26. 53. Heb. 12. 22

div.head: Q. What end and office were they created for?
div.p: A. To celebrate the Lords praises, and to execute his commands Isa. 6. 2, 3. Ps. 103. 20., specially towards the heirs of salvation Heb. 1. 14..

div.head: Q Do the Angels continue in that estate wherein they were first created?
div.p: A. Not all, for a great many fell away from that happy condition who are now become devils, Ioh. 8. 44. 2. Pet. 2. 4. Iude 6.

div.head: Q. May the rest also fall away, and perish with the devils?
div.p: A. No, because they are elected of God, and so for ever upholden in that good estate. 1 Tim. 5. 27.

div.head: CHAP. 8. Of the estate of man in Innocency by creation.
Q HOw doth the providence of God exercise it selfe towards man?
div.p: A. In a fourefold estate; the state of Innocency by creation afore the fall, the state of Corruption by and fince the fall, the state of grace in this world, and the state of Glory in the world to come.

div.head: Q What was the state of man in Innocency by by creation afore the fall?
div.p: A. God did as it were deliberate with himselfe, the father son and spirit consulting together about the making of man Gen. 1. 26., and therefore it must needs be that the state of man at the first by Gods creating of him, was very excellent.

div.head: Q. Wherein did his cheife excellency consist?
div.p: A. In that he was made in the Iikenesse and image of God. Gen 1. 26. 27.

div.head: Q. What was that image of God?
div.p: A. Principally it stood in knowledge, righteousnesse, and true holynesse Col. 3. 10. Eph. 4. 24. Eccles. 7. 29.

div.head: Q. What was the knowledge that man was indued withall in that estate?
div.p: A. He did then truely, and distinctly know God, and the will of God Rom. 1. 19, 20. Ier. 31. 34., with the nature of the creatures Gen. 2. 19, 20, 23., and his own present happinesse Gen. 2. 24. Rom. 2. 15..

div.head: Q. What was that holynesse and righteousnesse?
div.p: A. That his will, and affections, with his whole heart and soule, was exactly conformable to the revealed will of God.

div.head: Q. Did not man in that state besides this conformty to God enjoy communion with God?
div.p: A. Yes, at that time there was great amity, and love betweene God and man Gen. 1. 29., all the destance that is now being risen since as the effect and fruit of sinne.

div.head: Q Did not the place where man was then put, something set forth his happinesse in that estate?
div.p: A. Yes; for he was placed in Paradise which was an excellent garden planted by God himselfe, and abounding with all delight, and pleasures. Gen. 2. 8, 9, 10, 15.

div.head: Q But seeing man was to worke and labour in the garden in dressing and keeping it, how doth this agree with happinesse?
div.p: A. Yea very well, because happinesse doth not consist in idlenesse; and as for his labour, it then was, and alwayes should have bin without paine, and wearinesse, if man had continued in that estate.

div.head: Q. What was mans condition at that time in respect of food and raiment?
div.p: A. The earth at that time was furnished with plenty, and variety of wholesome and delightsome fruits, and he had liberty to eat of them all, except onely of the tree of knowledge of good and evill. Gen. 2. 16.

div.head: Q. His food then was excellent; but what was his apparrell?
div.p: A. Such was the strength and beauty of his body outwardly, and the perfection of Gods image, wherewith he was clothed inwardly, that he had no neede of other bodily apparrell either in respect of shame or season of weather, and therefore he lived naked. Gen. 2. 25.

div.head: Q. What was his condition in respect of other creatures?
div.p: A. All the fishes of the Sea, all the birds of the ayre, and beasts of the field were all of them subject to his dominion, and rule, Gen. 1. 20, 28, and 2. 19, 20.

div.head: Q. But what helpe had he in his condition against solitarinesse?
div.p: A. The Lord saw it was not good for a man to be alone, and that amongst all the other creatures there was not a meete helpe for him, and therefore of a ribbe of his side he made a woman and brought her to the man to be his wife. Gen. 2. 18. &c.

div.head: Q But why was man created last of all ceatures?
div.p: A. This also doth declare his excellency and happy estate by creation; for being made last it appeareth thereby, that he was under God the end for which the other creatures were made, and so was more excellent then they, as the end is more excellent then the meanes.

div.head: Q How else did the time of mans creation declare his happinesse?
div.p: A. It appeareth thereby, that God would not make him before he had first provided for him, but brought him into the world as into a great store-house already fully furnished with all variety of good things that might be for his service and comfort.

div.head: CHAP. 9. Of the fall of our first Parents.

Q. YOu have already shewed the state of man in Innocency by creation, what things are to be
dered concerning the state of corruption?
div.p: The beginning thereof which was the fall of our first parents, and the consequents of that fall in respect of sinne and punnishment.

div.head: Q. What Scriptures do prove that Adam and Eve did fall from that state of innoceney and purity where in they were created?
div.p: A. Many, but most especially the third chap. of Genes. Eccles. 7. 29. Isa. 43. 27. Rom. 5. 12, 18, 19. 1. Tim. 2, 14.

div.head: Q Who did fall?
div.p: A. First Eve 1 Tim 2. 14, then Adam Gen 3. 6., and in him all man kind Rom. 5. 12, 19. & 3. 23. 1 Cor. 15. 22. that proceed from Adam after the ordinary way.

div.head: Q. How did man fall?
div.p: A. By transgression 1 Tim 2. 14. Rom. 5. 15. 17, 18 and disobedience Rom 5. 19: to the commandement of God, which was that they should not eate of the tree of knowledge of good and evill Gen. 3. 6. and 2. 17..

div.head: Q Wherein was this such a great offence? for it may seeme a small matter to eat an apple or other fruit forbidden.
div.p: A. This sinne was not small, but very great, as comprehending in it an heape and multitude of many other hainous evills.

div.head: Q What are some of those evils comprehended in this sinne?
div.p:
A. There was great umbeliefe to doubt of the
truth of Gods threatning, there was great Idolatry in preferring the counsell of Satan afore the commandment of God, and great blasphemy in yeelding to Satan, when he said God forbade them that tree because he did envy their happinesse.

div.head: Q. What evill else was there in that offence?
div.p: A. There was discontent with their estate, though it was exceeding good, abominable pride that would be like unto God, and horrible unthankfulnesse to sinne against God that had so highly advanced them.

div.head: Q. What further evil was in it?
div.p: A. There was curiosity in desiring to know more then God would have them to know; also also they sinned needlesly and wilfully, that commandement being so equall and easie to have beene kept.

div.head: Q. How may that appeare?
div.p: A. Because man then had no inward Concupiscence or corruption of nature, as we now have, that could move him to breake the commandement, nor was he any necessitated thereto through any want, having such variety and abundance of other fruits, whereof he might freely eat.

div.head: Q. What may be a last particular to shew the hainousnesse of this first offence?
div.p:
A. Man shewed himselfe herein to be wretchedly carelesse of the good of his posterity, to
whom in this act he was both unkind and Cruell.

div.head: Q. How may that appeare?
div.p: A. In that by this meanes he brought sinne and misery upon them all. Rom. 5. 12, 18, 19. 1 Cor. 15. 22.

div.head: Q. Why should this sinne of Adam bring the guilt of sinne and misery upon all his posterity?
div.p: A. Because he stood at this time as a publike person in the roome of all mankind, we being all considered in him as members in the head, as children in his loines, as debtors in our surety, and as branches in our roote.

div.head: Q. VVhat was the cause of this great and lamentable offence?
div.p: A. It was not any weaknesse or want of power in man to stand; for being made in Gods Image he might have stood if he would.

div.head: Q. You thinke then he was not compelled and forced to sinne and breake the commandment?
div.p: A. God was so farre from forcing him to sin that he gave him power to have obeyed, and threatned him with death in case of disobedience.

div.head: Q. But might not Satan compell him to it?
div.p: A. Satan could doe nothing against him by compulsion or constraint, and therefore doth onely assault him by Crafty and subtill perswasions?

div.head: Q. VVhat then was the cause of this their sinne?
div.p: A. The principall cause was man himselfe in abusing his owne freewill, to receive the temptation, which he might have resisted if he would, Eccles. 7. 29.

div.head: Q How farre was Satan a cause of that first offence?
div.p: A. Though he could not constraine man to sinne without his own consent, yet he was justly to be blamed for that sinne of man, in that it was through his entisements that man was drawen unto it.

div.head: Q. How did he entise man to it?
div.p: A. By abusing the serpent to seduce the woman, and the helpe of the woman to seduce the man. Gen. 3. 1, 6.

div.head: Q. VVhat are the effects and fruits of his Fall?
div.p: A. By means of this Fall both the Serpent and Satan became accursed, and Adam and Eve and their posterity plunged into a depth of sin and misery. Gen. 3.

div.head: CHAP. 10. Of Sinne; the definition of it, and the distribution into Original and actual.
Q. WHat is sinne?
div.p: A. Transgression of the moral Law of God, by a Creature that is bound to keepe it?

div.head: Q. Why is sin said to be a transgression of the Law?
div.p:
A. Because the Apostle Iohn doth expresly
so call it 1 Ioh. 3. 4., and elsewhere it is said where there is no law Rom. 4. 15., there is no transgression

div.head: Q. Why say you that sinne is a Transgression of the law of God onely? for are not Transgressions of the Lawfull commandements of parents and other Superiors, sins also?
div.p: A. Yes so farre as they tend to the dishonour of Superiors, such Transgressions are also sins; but the reason of that is because obedience to the lawfull commands of Superiors is enjoyned in the fifth commandement of the law of God, in which respect God is said to be the onely Lawgiver Iam. 4. 12.

div.head: Q. But why doe you make sinne a Transgression onely of the morall law, sith unbeliefe and Impenitency though they be against the gospel, are also sinnes, and so were violations of the Ceremoniall law that was given to Israel by Moses?
div.p: A. Violation of the Ceremonies by the people of Israel was a sinne, because the observation of them was enjoyned to that people in the second commandement of the moral law, like a •… the observation of baptisme and the Lords Supper are now enjoyned to Christians by the same Commandement.

div.head: Q And why are unbeliefe and Impenitenci •… sinnes?
div.p:
A. Though these be directly against the Gospel, yet they are also sinnes when they are
found in them to whom the Gospels comes, as being against the first commandement of the law, which enioynes obedience to God in whatsoever he hath shewed or shall shew to be his wil.

div.head: Q. Why do you make sinne a Transgression of the law by a creature?
div.p: A. Because God the Creator may do things forbidden in the Law, and yet not sinne, as to kill and destroy; because the law is not a rule to him but to us, his owne will being his rule, Eph. 1. 11. Ps. 115. 3.

div.head: Q. Why is it added, by a Creature bound unto it?
div.p: A. Because though Angels may sinne, yet many things in the law, specially in the fifth and seventh commandement are not applyable to Angels; and as for other Creatures, the Law is no rule to them at all.

div.head: Q. Who among men are tainted with sinne?
div.p: A. All that are meere men, none excepted Eccles. 7. 20. Rom. 3. 23. and 5. 12.

div.head: Q. How many sorts of sinne are there?
div.p: A. Besides that first offence of eating the forbidden fruit, there is the corruption of nature which is usually called originall sinne, and the sinnes of life which are usually called actuall.

div.head: Q. What is the nature of originall sinne? wherein doth it consist?
div.p: A. It consists in the losse of Gods Image wherein man was created at the first Rom. 7. 17. Eph 21. and 4, 18., and in a contrary vitiousnesse instead thereof Gen. 6. 5. and 8. 21. Rom. 7. 23.,

div.head: Q. What is the measure or greatnesse of this sinne?
div.p: A. It contaynes not onely some one or few particular evils, but a masse of all iniquities, even the most abominable that can be named or Imagined Rom. 3. 12. 13. &c.

div.head: Q. How farre doth this sinne extend?
div.p: A. It overspreads the whole race of mankind as a contagious leprosie and epidemical disease Rom. 3. 10, 11. and 5. 12. and 3. 23., and infects all the powers and parts both of soule and body 1 Thes. 5. 23. Ier. 10. 14. Tit. 1. 15. Rom. 8. 7. Gal. 5. 24. Rom. 6. 19..

div.head: Q. How is this sinne propagated?
div.p: A. It is conveyed from parents to children not by imitation but by generation; Gen 5. 3. Psal. 51. 5. Iob 14. 4. Ioh. 3. 6.

div.head: Q. What do you understand by actuall sinnes?
div.p: A. All omissions of good 2 Eph. 3. 1, 2. mat. 25. 42, 43 &c. Iam. 4. 17.. and failing in the maner of doing it Iam. 4. 3., and all committing evill whether in thoughts Gen. 6. 5., words Math. 12. 34, 36, 37., or deeds Col. 1▪ 21. Isa. 59. 6., against any of the commandements of God.

div.head: Q. Who are guilty of actuall sinnes?
div.p: A. All the children of men Rom 3. 10. 11 &c. Iam. 3. 2. 1 Ioh. 1. 8. Eccles. 7. 20.; and they that sinne the least, yet doubtlesse would do more if the Lord did not restraine them Isa. 37. 29. Hos. 2. 6, 7..

div.head: Q. But though all men be thus defiled with sinne, yet may not a naturall man doe some things that are good?
div.p: A. Hee may do things that are good for the act or matter of them Rom. 2. 14, 15., but his person not being accepted Gen. 4. 4., and hsi heart Gen. 6. 5. Ier. 17. 9.. so exceedingly corrupted, therefore all that he doth as it proceeds from him, is corrupt also and so most odious unto God math. 12. 33, 34, 35. and 15. 19, 20. Pro. 15. 8. and 28. 9.,

div.head: CHAP. 11. Of the Punishment of Sinne.
Q. SIth all the children of men are thus wofully defiled with sinne, what punnishment is due by reason of the Sinne?
div.p: A. In one word all kind of death Gen. 2. 17. Rom. 5. 12. and 6. 23., and Cursednesse Col. 3. 10.. which in the particulars containes all the plagues that are written in Gods book Deut. 28. 15. and 29. 20., and many more which are not written Deut. 28. 61..

div.head: Q. What are the generall heads of those plagues?
div.p: A. They are temporall, and spirituall, and eternall.

div.head: Q. What are the temporall plagues.
div.p:
A. The Cursing of the earth Gen. 3. 17, 18., and the Creatures made subject to vanity Rom. 8. 20, 21., and the bodyes of men become subject to plagues and paines and
death Deut. 28 21, 22, 27, 35, 48. Gen 3. 19..

div.head: Q. What else?
div.p: A. In name ignominie and reproach, both alive and after death Deut. 28. 20, 37. Pro. 10. 7., and calamities in mens wives, children and friends Deut. 28 30, 41.

div.head: Q. VVhat other outward miseries are there?
div.p: A. In the outward estate poverty and losses Deut. 28. 16, 17, 18, 38, 39, 40., and their very blessings to be turned into Curses mal. 2. 2. Psal. 69. 22.,

div.head: Q. VVhat are the spiritual miseries?
div.p: A. The losse of Gods Image and all comfortable communion with him Rom. 3. 23. Eph. 4. 18. Isa. 59 2., with bondage to the divell Eph. 2. 2. 2 Cor 4. 4. 2 Tim. 2. 26., and a necessity of sinning math. 12. 33, 34, 35. Ioh. 9. 35. Rom. 6. 16, 18, 19, 20..

div.head: Q. VVhat else are the spirituall miseries?
div.p: A. VVhen men are given up unto more sinn Psal. 81. 12. Rom. 1. 24, 29, 28, as unto hardnesse of heart exod. 9. 12., blindnesse of mind Isa. 6. 9, 10. and strong delusions 2 Thes. 2. 11.,

div.head: Q VVhat is the eternall miserie?
div.p: A. Damnation and destruction in another world, 2 Thes. 1. 9. Iob. 5. 29.

div.head: Q. VVherein doth that consist?
div.p:
A. In being deprived of all good, and in
the contrary sense and feeling of evill.

div.head: Q. VVhat good shall the wicked be then deprived of?
div.p: A. They shall then be deprived of the favourable presence of God math. 25. 41. 2 Thes. 1. 9., of the joyes of heaven Luk. 13. 28. Rev. 21. 27. and 22. 15., of the society of the Saints Luk. 13. 28. Psal. 1. 5., and all comfort of the Creature, Luk. 16. 24, 25.,

div.head: Q. And what evill shall they then have the feeling of?
div.p: A. They shall feele unspeakeable torment both in soule and body, Mar. 9. 43, 44, 45. Luk. 16. 23, 24.

div.head: Q. VVhat will be the effect thereof?
div.p: A. It wil cause weeping & gnashing of teeth Math. 13. 42. Luk. 13. 28., the former through griefe and dolour, and both of them through indignation and despaire

div.head: Q. If they must be deprived of heaven, and of the presence of God and of his Saints, what place and company shall they be in?
div.p: A. They shall be in hell as in a prison 1 Pet. 3. 19., or deepe pitt Isa. 30. 33., or lake that burneth with fire and brimstone Rev. 11. 8., and their company shall be no other but the divell and his Angels Math. 25. 41..

div.head: Q. This punishment of the damned is in it selfe most dreadfull and terrible, but how long shall it continue?
div.p: A. The thing were something lesse grievous, if this misery would ever have an end; but this is the aggravation of it that it must be everlasting, 2 Thes. 1. 9. Matth. 25. 41. 46. Matth. 9. 43, 44.

div.head: CHAP. 12. Of mans deliverance.

Q. HAving spoken of the state of man by creation, and his estate of corruption, let us now come to the third estate, the state of grace in this life; and first tell me whether there be any ability in man to deliver himselfe from his sinfull and miserable estate?
div.p: A. None at all; because man being dead in trespasses and sinnes, hath no more ability to recover himselfe to spirituall life, then he that is bodily dead to recover himselfe to bodily life. Eph. 2. 1. & 4. 18.

div.head: Q. How else may this inability of man appeare?
div.p: A. Man of himselfe is without strength Rom. 5. 6. to any thing that is good; and moreover, if he had power unto it, yet he hath no will to seek after God Isa. 65. 1. Rom. 3. 11., but to depart further and further from him Gen. 3. 8. yea to expresse all enmity against him Rom. 8. 7.

div.head: Q. What may be a further reason to shew that man cannot deliver himselfe?
div.p:
A. Man being a creature, is but finite; and the
Majesty and Justice of God which by sinne is offended and wronged, is infinite.

div.head: Q. What doe you infer from thence?
div.p: A. Because there can be nothing in a finite sinning nature to satisfie an infinite offended Majesty; but such a nature must be ever in satisfying, and never have satisfied; therefore it was not possible that man should deliver himselfe from his sinfull and miserable estate.

div.head: Q If man could not deliver himselfe, might be not be delivered by some other creature?
div.p: A. There is no man that can give a ransom to redeem another, so much as from bodily death Psal. 49. 7. and much lesse from spiritual and eternal death.

div.head: Q. But if one man could not redeem another, what doe you say of other creatures?
div.p: A. Other creatures are none of them of the same nature with man, and are all of them but finite, even the Angels themselves; and therefore none of them can make satisfaction to the infinite Majesty of God.

div.head: Q. If infinite justice must needs he satisfied, and neither man nor other creature are able to doe this; how then was there any possibility that man should ever be delivered from this wretched estate?
div.p:
A. The mercy of God is so infinite that he might be willing that man should be delivered, and his wisdome such that he could finde out some way and means of deliverance; and his
power such that he was able to accomplish the way which his wisdom should devise; and therefore there was a possibility that man should be delivered.

div.head: Q. But whether is there any way of deliverance already found out, and man actually recovered?
div.p: A. Yes, the Lord hath wrought redemption, and raised up an horne of salvation for his people, Psal. 111. 9. Luke 1. 69.

div.head: Q. Is God himselfe then the Authour of mans deliverance?
div.p: A. Mans misery being sinne against God, and punishment from God, therefore God onely must be the authour of his deliverance, if he ever be delivered.

div.head: Q. What moved God to work mans deliverance?
div.p: A. Not because he had any need of man e, for he could have been absolute and alsufficient of himselfe, if all men had perished everlastingly, as he was before man had any being. Iob 22. 3. & 35. 7. Rom. 11. 25.

div.head: Q. Did God procure mans deliverance, because man did so deserve?
div.p: A. Man deserved it not, but the contrary, because he fell wilfully from that happy estate wherein he was created, whenas he might have continued happy if he would: therefore it had been no unrighteous thing if God had left him in that misery whereinto he had brought himselfe, Pro. 1. 31.

div.head: Q. Did the Lord worke the deliverance of man, because man did importunately seek and sue unto him for the same?
div.p: A. Man did not seek and sue unto God at all, but fled from him, Gen 3. 8. Rom. 3. 11. And if he had sought unto God for helpe, God was not bound to afford it; and how much lesse when he sought it not?

div.head: Q. If God did not worke the deliverance of man because himselfe had need of it, or because man did desire it, what then was the cause that moved him to it?
div.p: A. Onely his free grace, mercy, and love, Iohn 3. 16. Eph. 2. 4, 5. Titus 3. 4, 5.

div.head: Q. What is the true way and means of deliverance?
div.p: A. Onely the Lord Jesus Christ, Genes 3. 15. Acts 4. 12. 1 Iohn 5. 12.

div.head: CHAP. 13. Of the person of Christ, and his divine and humane nature?
Q. WHat things are to be known and believed concerning Christ?
div.p: A. His Person, his Office, his Actions, the benefits that come by him, and the means how we are made partakers of him and all his benefits.

div.head: Q. What is his person?
div.p: A. It is God and man united together in one person.

div.head: Q. How may it be proved that Christ is God?
div.p: A. By sundry places of Scripture, wherein he is expresly so called, Isa. 9. 6. Iohn 1. 1. Rom. 9. 5. Phil. 2. 6. 1 Iohn 5. 2 • .

div.head: Q. How else?
div.p: A. Because Eternity Isa. 9. 6. Pro. 8. 22. Iohn 8. 58. & 17. 5. Col. 1. 15. Rev. 1. 8. Omnipotency Rev. 1. 8. Iohn 3. 31. Omniscience Iohn 21. 7. & 2. 24, 25. Rev. 2. 23. Mat. 9. 4. and Omnipresence Iohn 3. 13. Mat. 28. 20. Eph. 3. 17. which are properties peculiar to God, are all of them ascribed unto Christ.

div.head: Q. How else may the Godhead of Christ be proved?
div.p: A. Because the creation of the world 1 Iohn 1. 3. 10. Col. 1. 16. the forgivenesse of sinnes Mat. 6. 9. the working of miracles Luke 8. 31. & 4. 36. Mat. 10 1. which are workes that can be done by none but God, are all of them ascribed to him as the authour of them; and because he is made a lawfull object of divine worship Heb. 1. 6. Iohn 14. 1.

div.head: Q. Why was it requisite that Christ our Saviour should be God?
div.p: A. That he might beare the weight of Gods wrath without sinking under the same Exod. 27. 1. that he might overcome death Acts 2. 24. and his sufferings might be of sufficient worth and value to satisfie the infinite justice of God Acts 20. 28.

div.head: Q. Is Christ also truely partaker of the nature of man?
div.p: A. Yes, for he is frequently called man, and the sonne of man 1 Tim. 2. 5. Mat. 8. 20. and said to be made flesh Iohn 1. 14. and partaker of flesh and blood Heb. 2. 14. Luke 24. 39.

div.head: Q. Why was it requisite that he should be man?
div.p: A. That he might suffer death for us Heb. 2. 14. sanctisie our nature Heb. 2. 11. and that we might have accesse with boldnesse unto God Heb. 4 15, 16.

div.head: Q. But sith he was God from everlasting, how came be to be man also?
div.p: A. When the fulnesse of time was come Gal. 4. 4. he became man, not after the ordinary and usuall way of generation by man and woman together, but he was conceived by the holy Ghost in the womb of a Virgin, without a father Mat. 1. 20. Luke 1. 34, 55. Heb. 7. 3.

div.head: Q. Sith there are two natures in Christ, the Divine and humane, whether is Christ then two persons?
div.p: A. By no means, but one onely, 1 Cor. 8. 6. 1 Tim. 2. 5.

div.head: Q. But is not Christ a person in respect of his Godhead?
div.p: A. Yes, the second person in the blessed Trinity.

div.head: Q. Is not another man who hath the whole nature of man in him, both body and soule, a perfect person?
div.p: A. Yes, it is even so.

div.head: Q. Why then is not the humane nature in Christ a distinct person?
div.p: A. Because it never had subsisting and being of it selfe, but in the person of the Son of God being assumed unto it from the first moment of its being, Heb. 2. 16.

div.head: Q. If both the humane and divine nature be in Christ, and yet Christ but one person; is then the Godhead become the manhood, and the manhood the Godhead?
div.p: A. Not so; this Union of two natures in one person doth not confound the two natures, nor destroy the properties of either; but these still remain unconfounded and distinct in that one person.

div.head: CHAP. 14. Of the Office of Christ to be a Mediator.
Q. HAving spoken of the person of Christ, tell in the next place what is Christs Office?
div.p: A. His Office in the generall is to be a Mediator between God and man, to worke reconciliation betwixt them. 1 Tim. 25. 2 Cor. 5. 18, 19.

div.head: Q. What need was there of such a Mediator?
div.p: A. Very much need, because by the sinne of man there was now grown enmity between them, God being offended with man, and man being enemy to God. Rom. 5. 9, 10. Col. 2. 21.

div.head:
Q. Is Christ the onely Mediator? or are there
not others that may be mediators also?
div.p: A. Properly there is no other mediator between God and man but Christ onely, 1 Tim. 2. 5. Iohn 14. 6.

div.head: Q. Who gave Christ a Commission or calling to the Office of a mediator?
div.p: A. As no man can lawfully intrude himselfe into any office without a lawfull calling, no more did Christ intrude himselfe into the office of a Mediator, but was lawfully called and authorized thereunto by the father, Isa 42. 1, 6. Iohn 6. 29. & 10. 36. Heb. 5. 4, 5.

div.head: Q. How was he furnished with gifts and abilities for discharge of this office?
div.p: A. As God never calleth any to any office, but he gives them gifts requisite thereto: so Christ was furnished with all wisdom & knowledge, and other gifts of the spirit, that might fully fit him for his office of Mediator, Col. 2. 3. Isa. 11. 2. & 61. 1. & Heb. 1. 9. Iohn 3. 34.

div.head: Q. Whether is Christ Mediator according to his humane nature, or according to his divine?
div.p: A. The office of mediation belongeth to whole Christ, as he is God and man, and not in respect of either nature alone.

div.head: Q. How may that appeare?
div.p:
A. A Mediator should be a fit and middle person to deale between two that are at variance: but if our mediator be considered as God onely, he should then be too high to treat with man,
and had he been man only he should have been too low for God.

div.head: Q. VVhat may be a further reason thereof?
div.p: A. If the acts of his mediation doe proceed from him, being considered onely as God, they then cannot be applicatory unto us; and if they proceed from him onely as man, they then cannot be of sufficient value to be satisfactory unto God.

div.head: Q. Doe you then think that in the execution of his office of mediator both the natures doe joyntly concurre?
div.p: A. It is even so indeed; God-man, whose Christ is our mediator.

div.head: Q. How long hath Christ had this office?
div.p: A. In respect of Gods decree he was appointed to it from eternity 1 Pet. 1. 20. 2 Tim. 1. 9. in respect of vertue and efficacy he was mediator from the beginning of the world when need was Gen. 315. Rev. 13. 8. Heb. 138.

div.head: Q. But when was he manifested in the flesh?
div.p: A. In respect of his manifestation in the flesh, he was given in the fulnesse of time in these latter daies, 1 Pet. 1. 20. Gal. 4. 4. 1 Tim. 2. 6.

div.head: Q. VVhat is the effect and benefit of his mediatorship?
div.p: A. Hereby God and man that were at enmity are reconciled together againe, and made one, Col. 1. 20. Eph. 1. 10. & 2. 14, 15.

div.head: CHAP. 15. Of the covenant between God and man, the covenant of worke, and the covenant of grace, and the difference between them.
Q. HOw doth Christ as Mediator reconcile God and man again?
div.p: A. By making a new Covenant and agreement betwixt them, which is called the covenant of grace?

div.head: Q. Is the covenant of grace made with respect to Christ?
div.p: A. Yea, had it not been for Christs sake, and through his mediation, God would never have made such covenant with man.

div.head: Q. How may that be proved?
div.p: A. This covenant is said to be confirmed in Christ Isai. 3. 17. and Christ is said to be the Mediator of the covenant Heb. 8. 6. & 9. 15. & 12. 24. the Angell of the covenant Mal. 3. 1. and sometimes the Covenant it selfe Gal. 42. 6. & 49. 8.

div.head: Q What is this covenant of grace.
div.p: A. That wherein God for Christ his sake promiseth forgivenesse of sinnes, and everlasting happinesse to them that believe on Christ.

div.head: Q Is there not mention in Scripture of some other covenant of God to man, besides this covenant of grace in Christ?
div.p:
A. Yes, there is that generall covenant with mankind, that the word should not be drowned
any more with water, and that the succession of day and night, and other seasons, should be maintained as long as the earth shall endure. Gen. 9. 11. & 8. 22.

div.head: Q These Covenants are onely concerning externall and earthly lessings; but is there not some covenant concerning everlasting happinesse, besides that covenant of grace in Christ?
div.p: A. Yes, that which is usually called the covenant of works, Gal. 4. 24, 25. Rom. 10. 5.

div.head: Q What is that covenant of works?
div.p:
A. That whereby God promiseth all life and happinesse, upon condition of perfect obedience to the law in a mans own person, with a threatning of everlasting death & cursednesse for the least transgression, Rom.
• 0. 5. Gal. 3. 10. Gen. 2, 17.

div.head: Q VVherein do these two covenants differ?
div.p: A. The covenant of works being made with man in innocency may be called a covenant of amity or friendship between God and man being friends; but the other is a covenant of gracious reconciliation, when sinne had brought in enmity betwixt them, 2 Cor. 5. 19, 20.

div.head: Q. VVhat is another difference?
div.p: A. The one belongs to Adam, and all his posterity; the other belongs onely to the elect, or at the most onely to such as have the Gospel preached to them, Eph. 2. 12.

div.head: Q Is there not some difference in regard of the blessings promised to either of them?
div.p: A. Yes for the one promiseth life upon condition of perfect obedience; but if sinne be once committed, it knows of no forgivenesse, nor recovery Gen. 2. 17. but the other promiseth forgivenesse of sinnes Ier. 31. 34. and renovation of our natures Ezek 36, 26, 27. and to write the Law in our hearts Ier. 31, 33.

div.head: Q How do they differ in regard of the conditions of them?
div.p: A. The one promiseth nothing but upon condition of fulfilling the law in our own persons Rom. 10. 5., which to man since the fall is utterly impossible Rom. 8 3.; but the covenant of grace promiseth life upon condition of believing in another, the Lord Jesus Christ Acts 16 31.

div.head: Q. VVhat are the effects of either of these covenants?
div.p: A. The one now works nothing but the discovery of sinne Rom. 3. 20., and bondage Gal. 4. 24, and wrath Rom. 4 15., requiring many things, but not giving any power to perform Rom. 8 3., but the other worketh in us what it requireth of us, being the ministration of the spirit, and righteousnesse and life 2 Cor. 3. 6, 8, 9.; and the power of God to salvation Rom. 1. 16.

div.head: Q. VVhat is the continuance of either of them?
div.p:
A. The one is broken by the sinne of man Ier. 31. 32., and abrogated to them that are in Christ Gal. 5. 18. Rom. 6. 14. but
the other shall never be removed nor disanulled to them that have once truly believed in him Isa. 54. 10. Ier. 32. 40.

div.head: Q. VVas the covenant of grace revealed and dispensed in the times afore Christs Incarnation, or only since his comming in the flesh?
div.p: A. There hath been the same covenant of grace for substance, in all times and ages of the Church, since the fall of man till this day, Gen. 3. 15. & 15. 5, 6. Iohn 8. 56. Acts 15, 11. Heb. 13. 8.

div.head: Q. But hath there not been some difference between the administration of the covenant of grace in former times, and in these daies.
div.p: A. Yes, there hath been difference in regard of the manner of administration, and therefore it is that they are called two Covenants, or Testaments, the Old and the New Ier. 31. 31. Heb. 8 8, 13: when for substance it is but the same.

div.head: Q. VVherein stands that different manner of administration?
div.p: A. Then it was more burden some in regard of the multitude of Ceremonies and sacrifices, now it is more easie; Then it was more darke, in regard of Types and shadows, now apparent and cleer.

div.head: Q. VVhat may be the further difference?
div.p:
A. Now there is more power and efficacy of the Spirit, and the graces of it, in the hearts of Gods people genreally, then was then: and
whereas then it was only to be one people, now it is to all Nations.

div.head: CHAP. 16. How Christ is the Prophet, Priest, and King unto his people, and in particular of his Propheticall Office.

Q. YOu have shewed that the Office of Christ in generall is to be a Mediator, to reconcile God and man together by meanes of the new covenant, or covenant of grace; tell me now what are the speciall parts of his Mediatorship?
div.p: A. He is a Prophet, a Priest, and King.

div.head: Q. How may it be proved that Christ hath this threefold Office of Prophet, Priest, and King?
div.p: A. First, by the condition of his people, lying under a threefold misery of ignorance, estrangement from God, and inability to recover themselves, and return unto God again,

div.head: Q. How doth this prove it.
div.p: A. The first of these miseries is holpen by Christs Propheticall office, the second by his Priestly, and the third by his Kingly.

div.head: Q. How else may this threefold office of Christs be proved?
div.p: A. By the order and manner of bestowing salvation upon his people, which must first be revealed and made known, then purchased and procured, and lastly effectually applied.

div.head: Q. And how doth this prove it?
div.p: A. The first of these is done by Christs Propheticall office, the second by his Priestly, and the third by his Kingly.

div.head: Q. VVhat may be a further proofe of this three fold Office of Christ?
div.p: A. The practice of Christ, who first lived as a Prophet teaching the will of God secondly as a Priest he offered himselfe on the Crosse; and then as a King he applies unto his people all the benefits of his passion.

div.head: Q. Come we now to the particulars, and tell me how it may be proved that Christ is a Prophet to his people?
div.p: A. Because he is expresly so called Deut. 18. 18 Acts 3. 22, 23., as also by other titles importing the same thing;

div.head: Q. VVhat are those other titles?
div.p: A. He is called Counsellor Isai 9 6., Messenger Mal. 3. 1., Doctor or Master Mat. 23. 10., Apostle Heb. 3. 1., Speaker Heh. 12. 25., the Shepheard and Bishop of our soules 1 Pet. 2. 25., the faithfull and true witnesse Rev. 1. 5. & 3 14.

div.head: Q VVhat is the work of Christ as a Prophet?
div.p: A. To reveale and make known to his people the counsell and will of God, Deut. 18. 18. Iohn 1. 18. & 4. 25. & 15 15. Matth. 11. 27.

div.head: Q How doth he this?
div.p: A. Outwardly by such means as he hath appointed, and inwardly by the teaching and illumination of his holy Spirit.

div.head: Q. VVhat are the outward meanes?
div.p:
A. They are divers and sundry, according as
it pleased him Heb 1. 1.; but chiefly they are the holy Scriptures Iohn 5. 39 Col. 3 16., and the ministery of men appointed to speak in his name Eph. 4. 1 • , 12. Luke 10. 16. 2 Cor. 5. 20.

div.head: Q. What is the teaching of the holy Spirit?
div.p: A. It is that inward work of the holy Ghost upon the soule, whereby the outward teaching is made efficacious and powerfull for opening the understanding and humbling the heart to embrace the truth and will of God, Iohn 16. 13. & 14. 26. 1 Iohn 2. 27

div.head: Q. When hath Christ performed his office and function of a Prophet unto his people?
div.p: A. Both when he was upon earth in his own person Isai 42. 1, 2 & 61. 1, 2. Mat. 4. 25. & 9. 35., and also in all times and ages of the Church, both afore his incarnation 1 Pet. 1. 11. & 3. 19., and since his Assention into heaven Mat. 28. 19, 20.

div.head: Q. How much of the will of God doth this Prophet make known unto his people?
div.p: A. All that is requisite for our Salvation; Iohn 15 15. & 4. 25. & 16. 13. & Deut. 18. 18.

div.head: Q. What then is to be thought of all Doctrines, Traditions, Revelations and Ordinances which he hath not appointed?
div.p: A. They are all to be rejected and accursed Iohn 8. 20. Gal. 1. 8, 9. 1 Iohn 4. 1. 2 Iohn 9. 10., as being injurious to the perfection and fulnesse of the Propheticall office of Christ:

div.head: CHAP. 17. Of the Priesthood of Christ.
Q. IS Christ also a Priest?
div.p: A. Yes, and is frequently so called, Psal. 110. 4. Heb. 2. 17. & 3. 1. & 4. 14, 15. & 5. 5, 6, 10. & 8. 1. & 9. 11.

div.head: Q Was he a Priest after the order of Aaron?
div.p: A. No, but after the order of Melchizedek, Psa. 110. 4 Heb. 7. 11, 21.

div.head: Q. How may that appeare?
div.p:
A. Aaron was of the Tribe of Levi, but Christ was of the Tribe of Iudah
Heb. 7. 13, 14.; and whereas Aaron had father and mother, Christ as he was man was without a father, and as God without mother Heb. 7. 3.

div.head: Q. How else?
div.p: A. Aaron and his successors being sinners, had need to offer sacrifice first for their owne sinnes, and then for the peoples: but Christ being altogether without sinne, did offer sacrifice onely for the people. Heb. 5. 3. & 9. 7. & 7. 26, 27.

div.head: Q. Is there not some difference between the Priesthood of Aaron and Christs Priesthood, in respect of the manner of entrance in the same and continuance therein?
div.p:
A. Yes, for Aaron and his successors were ordained without an oath; but Christ with an oath Heb. 7. 21.. And whereas the Priests of the law died and had successors, Christ hath an unchangeable
Priesthood, continuing Priest for ever Heb. 7. 23, 24, 25.

div.head: Q. How doe these priesthoods differ in respect of the sacrifices offered thereby?
div.p: A. The one offered the bodyes and blood of beasts; but Christ offered up himselfe, and so was both Priest and Sacrifice, Heb. 9. 12, 14, 26.

div.head: Q. Is there not some difference in regard of the number of their Sacrifices?
div.p: A. The Sacrifices of the Law were many, because of their imperfections, but Christ hath offered up himselfe once for all, Heb. 7. 27. & 9. 25, 26. & 10. 12, 14.

div.head: Q. What are the workes performed by him as a Priest?
div.p: A. Oblation or offering a Sacrifice Heb. 8. 3., and making request or intercession for his people Heb. 7. 25.

div.head: Q. What was the Sacrifice which he offered?
div.p: A. Himself as he is man Eph. 5 2. Heb. 9. 26., his humane soule Isai 53. 10, 12., and body Heb. 10. 10.

div.head: Q. VVhat kind of Sacrifice was this?
div.p: A. It was bloody, or by blood Heb. 9. 12. 22., it was spotlesse Heb. 9. 14., and perfect Heb. 9. 26. & 10. 10, 12, 14, and most pleasing unto God Eph. 5. 2.

div.head: Q. VVhat Altar did he offer this Sacrifice upon?
div.p:
A. The Altar must need be heavenly, as the Priest and Sacrifice were; and the use of an Altar
being to sanctifie the gift, and therefore greater then it Mat. 23. 19.; and therefore it was not the crosse of wood, but the Godhead of Christ, which was the Altar on which he sacrificed himselfe Iohn 17 19. Heb 9 14.

div.head: Q. Whether is Christ the only Priest unto God in these daies, or are there not others who are Priests also?
