div.p: A. All Christians are called Priests to offer up unto God the spirituall Sacrifice of prayer and thanksgiving, and the like 1 Pet. 2. 5. Rev 1. 6.; but to be a Priest to offer up a Sacrifice propitiatory is proper and peculiar unto Christ onely Heb. 7. 28.

div.head: Q. What acts doth Christ perform in making intercession for his people?
div.p: A. He appeares in the presence of God for them Heb 9 24., presenting before God the vertue and value of his death and bloodshedding Heb. 12. 24. & 9. 12., with some expression of his will before God for their good Rom. 18 34. Iohn 17. 24.

div.head: Q. In what manner doth he make this intercession?
div.p: A. Not with teares and words, and prostrating of his body, as he did on earth, but in such a manner as is suitable to his state of glory.

div.head: Q. What are the benefits of this intercession of Christ?
div.p:
A. Forgivenesse of sinnes daily continued
and applied 1 Iohn 2. 1, 2., with continuance in Gods favour Iohn 17. 11. Luke 22. 32., and acceptance of our imperfect services 1 Pet. 2. 5. Exod. 28. 38. Rev. 8. 3.

div.head: Q. What are the benefits of this intercession?
div.p: A. Hereby believers are defended and secured against the accusations of all their enemies Rom. 8. 33, 34. Zecb 3 1, 2., with certainty of salvation in Heaven Heb. 7. 25. Iohn 17. 24..

div.head: CHAP. 18. Of the Kingly office of Christ.
Q. HAth Christ also the office of a King?
div.p: A. Yes, for he is often expresly so called Psal. 2. 6. Ier. 23. 5. Zech. 9. 9. Luke 1. 32, 33. Iohn 1. 49., and hath the ornaments of a King;

div.head: Q. What are those ornaments?
div.p: A. To sit upon a Throne Rev. 2. 21: Heb. 1. 8., to weare a Crown upon his head Heb. 2 9. Can. 3. 11. Revel. 19. 12., and to have a Scepter in his hand Psal. 45. 6. & Psal. 110. 2.

div.head: Q. How is he King of his people? as God onely, or as man also?
div.p: A. Not as God onely, but as Mediator, God and man in one person.

div.head: Q. How is that proved?
div.p:
A. Because he that was born and given to us hath the government upon his shoulders Isa. 9. 6., and he that was crucisied is made Lord and Christ Acts 2. 36.;
now to be born, and given, and crucified, cannot be said of God onely,

div.head: Q. How else may it appeare that Christ is King not as God onely, but as man also?
div.p: A. Because the time will come when he shall deliver up the Kingdome to the father 1 Cor. 15 24, 28. but as God he shall reign with the father unto all eternity.

div.head: Q. Is any work of Christ as King anywhere expresly ascribed unto him as man?
div.p: A. Yea, authority to execute judgement as a Kingly work; and this belongeth unto Christ as man, Iohn 5. 27.

div.head: Q. Over whom is Christ a King?
div.p: A. Over all creatures in Generall Heb. 2. 8. Phil. 2 10, 11., over the visible Church in speciall Psal. 2. 6. Zech. 9. 9., and over the elect in a most speciall manner above all other Iohn 17. 2, 6, 12. Eph. 1. 22.

div.head: Q How is he King over all creatures?
div.p: A. In sustaining and disposing of them all by his providence, as may be for his glory, and the good of the elect, Heb. 1. 3. Col. 1. 16. Pro. 8. 15, 16. Isa. 43. 14, 15.

div.head: Q. And how is he King of the visible Church?
Q How doth Christ all these things in the Church?
div.p: A. He doth them all by his word, which is therefore called the word of the Kingdome, Mat. 13. 19.

div.head: Q. And how is Christ King of the Elect?
div.p: A. Not onely by his providence, as over all creatures: nor only by his Word and Ordinances, as to the visible Church, but also by the speciall working of the grace of his holy Spirit in their hearts, Ezek. 36 26. Eph. 1 22. Col. 1 18.

div.head: Q. Hath not the Kingly office of Christ some that are enemies unto it?
div.p: A. Yes, sin and the world, the divel and death.

div.head: Q. VVhat are the acts of Christs Kingly office in respect of those his enemies, and the enemies of his Church and elect people?
div.p: A. To bridle Rom. 6. 14. 2 Kings 19. 28. Iob 1. 12. & 2. 6. and subdue Psa. 110. 1, 5, 6. Heb. 2 14. 1 Cos. 15. 25, 26. them all.

div.head: Q. VVhat are the properties of Christs Kingdom?
div.p: A. It is lawfull Psa. 2. 6. Mat. 28. 18. Luke 1 32., spirituall Rom. 14. 17. Iohn 18 36. Luke 17. 20., powerfull Rev. 1. 5. & 19. 16., righteous Psa. 45. 6, 7. Rev. 19. 11., large Psa. 2. 8. & 72. 8, 9, 10, 11., and everlasting Psa. 45. 6. Dan. 7. 14. Luke 1. 33.

div.head: CHAP. 19. Of Christ his humiliation.
Q. HAving spoken of the person & Offices of Christ, how are we in the next place to consider of his actions?
div.p: A. In a twofold estate: his state of humiliation, and his state of exaltation.

div.head: Q VVhat are the generall acts of his humiliation?
div.p: A. Laying aside the full manifestation of his divine Majesty for a time Phil. 2 7. Iohn 17. 5., and assuming unto him the nature of man Heb. 2. 14, 16. Iohn 1 14. Phil. 2. 7.

div.head: Q. VVhat else?
div.p: A. It was a great act of his humiliation, that he became subject to the law Gal. 4 4., and not onely a man, but in the meanest condition of men Phil. 2 7. Isai 53. 2, 3. Psal. 22. 6..

div.head: Q. VVhat may be evidences that he was a man of a very mean condition and state?
div.p: A. His poore birth, his afflicted and poore life, his shamefull and accursed death, with the things that follow afterward, do evidently shew the same.

div.head: Q. What was his poor birth?
div.p: A. He was born of a poor Virgin for his mother who was espoused to a Carpenter for her husband; and when he was born was wrapped in swadling clothes and layd in a manger, because there was no room for his poor mother in the Inne, Luke 2. 7.

div.head: Q. What else was the testimony of his poore birth?
div.p:
A. When he was presented to the Lord in
the temple with an offering, the offering was but a paire of turtle doves or two yong pigeons, which was an offering appointed at the birth of children of the poorest sort of people. Luk. 2. 24. Levit. 12. 8.

div.head: Q. What was his poore and afflicted life?
div.p: A. His fleeing into Aegypt from the rage of Herod Mat. 2. 14., his poverty in outward estate Mat. 8. 20. Luk. 8. 3., and his subjection to his parents Luk. 2. 51. as any other child.

div.head: Q. VVhat else were testimonies of his afflicted life?
div.p: A. His temptations from the divell Mat. 4. 1. Luke 4. 13., his wearysome journeys from place to place Acts 10. 38. Iohn 4. 6., and his manifold persecutions from the hands and tongues Iohn 8. 48. 52. 59. Luk. 4. 28. 29. of wicked men,

div.head: Q. What was his shamefull, painefull and accursed death?
div.p: A. It was his crucifying or death upon the Crosse 1 Phil. 2: 8., which was a death accursed by the Law Gal: 3. 13.

div.head: Q. Wherein was the shame of that death?
div.p: A. It was shamefull in that he was Crucified in the midst betwixt two theeves Mat. 27. 38., and Barabbas a Murtherer counted more worthy then he Mat: 27. 21.

div.head: Q. What else was the shame and paine of that death?
div.p: A. He was Crowned with thornes, and otherwayes derided by the people and priests, his hands and feete were nailed to the Crosse, and his side was pierced with a Speare to the effusion of water and blood, Math. 27. 29. 30. 31. Iohn 19. 34.

div.head: Q. What else was there in his death?
div.p: A: That which was the greatest of all was, that he endured a grievous agony with his fathers wrath, Mat. 26, 37. 38. and 27. 46.

div.head: Q What followed after his death?
div.p: A. He was buried in the grave Math. 27. 60., and continued under the power and dominion of death for a time Acts 2. 27.,

div.head: Q. What was the end of all this Humilation of Christ?
div.p: Q. That he might make satisfaction to the justice and honour of God, which had been wronged by our sinnes Rom. 3. 25. 1 Tim. 2. 5. 6. 1 Iob. 2. 1. 2., and to procure for us reconciliation with God and eternall life Rom. 5. 9. 10.,

div.head: Q. How came Christ to be liable to make satisfaction for our sinnes?
div.p: A. Because he voluntarily became our Surety, and so was to pay the debt that we were in unto God, Heb. 7. 22. Psal, 40. 7.

div.head: CHAP. 20. Of the exaltation of Christ, and his Resurrection from the dead.
Q. HAving considered of Christs Humiliation, how are wee in the next place to consider of his exaltation?
div.p: A. The exaltation of Christ is to be considered both in respect of his Godhead and his manhood, and in the severall degrees thereof.

div.head: Q. What is his exaltation in respect of his Godhead?
div.p: A. It is nothing else but the manifestation of that divine power and glory of his, which had beene so much concealed in all the time of his humiliation, Iohn 175. Rom. 1. 4:

div.head: Q And what is his exaltation in respect of his Manhood?
div.p: A. It consists partly in laying aside all those infirmities which it had beene subject unto in the time of Humiliation by hunger, thirst, wearinesse and the like, which are all of them removed and done away, 1 Cor. 15. 43.

div.head: Q. Wherein else doth this exaltation consist?
div.p: A. In that the humane nature of Christ was filled with all the glorious excellencies that a creature is capable of, and this both in respect of his soule Heb. 12. 2., and in respect of his body Phil. 3. 21.,

div.head: Q. Doth the bodie of Christ by meanes of his exultation or Glorification become infinite, or Omnipresent or in many places at once?
div.p: A. As the soule of Christ being Glorified doth still retaine the nature of a soule: so his bodie doth still retaine the essentiall properties of a bodie Math 28. 6. Luke 20. 39., and therefore is not infinite nor omnipresent, for that were to destroy its essentiall properties,

div.head: Q. VVhat are the degrees of Christs exaltation?
div.p: A. His resurrection from the dead, his ascention into heaven, and his sitting at the right hand of God.

div.head: Q. VVhat meane you by his resurrection from the dead?
div.p: A. I meane that his body which was dead was quickned againe 1 Pet. 3. 18. Rom: 14. 9., by the uniting together of his soule and body againe, which in death had been separated: and also that being quickned he came forth again out of the grave Mat: 28. 6. Iohn 20. 6. 7..

div.head: Q. VVhat certainty is there of this resurrection of Christ?
div.p: A. The scripture saith that Christ is risen indeed Luke 24. 34., and his resurrection hath beene witnessed by many cleare and pregnant Testimonies,

div.head: Q. VVhat are those testimonies?
div.p:
A. The blessed Angels did witnesse that Christ was risen from the dead Math: 28. 5, 6. Mark: 16. 6. 7. Luk. 24. 4, 5, 6.; so also did the watchmen which were set to have kept him from rising Math. 28. 11., and likewise certaine godly women Math. 28. 9. 10. Luk. 24. 9. 10., to whom he shewed himselfe alive after
his Resurrection.

div.head: Q. What further Testmonies was there of Christs resurrection?
div.p: A. The Apostles who were witnesses appoined of God for this end Act. 10. 41., doe frequently testifie the same Act. 2. 24. 32. and 3. 15. and 4. 10. 33. and 5. 30. 31. 32. and 10. 40. 1 Cor. 15. 4, 5, 6, 15..

div.head: Q. Did not Christ also declare his owne Resurrection by shewing himselfe upon earth after he was risen from the dead, afore he ascended into Heaven?
div.p: A. He shewed himselfe alive by appearing to many within the space of those forty dayes betweene his Resurrection and ascention Acts 1. 3.

div.head: Q. What are some of those apparitions of Christ in those dayes?
div.p: A. He appeared to Mary Magdalen Mark 16. 9.: and to other Godly Women Math: 28. 9. 10., to two disciples as they were going to Emmaus Luk. 24. 13., and to all the disciples together except Thomas Ioh. 2c. 19..

div.head: Q. To whom else?
div.p: A. To the disciples at another time and to Thomas being with them Ioh. 20 26., to seven of them at the sea of Tiberias Ioh. 21. 1. 2., to the Eleven a in Mountain of Galilee Mat. 28. 16., and upon the mount of Olives Acts 1. 12., and to above five hundred brethren at once 1 Cor. 15. 6..

div.head: Q. You have sufficiently shewed the certainty of Christs resurrection; tell likewise the time of it, when it was that he arose.
div.p: A. Hee rose againe the third day after he was put to death, 1 Cor 15. 4.

div.head: Q. By what power did he rise againe?
div.p: A. By the power of the father Act. 2. 24. Eph. 1. 19. 20., and his owne almighty power Ioh. 2. 19. and 10. 18..

div.head: Q. What were the ends of his Resurrection?
div.p: A. He rose againe to shew the dignity of his person Rom. 1. 4., to fulfill the scriptures Luk. 24. 46. Psa. 16. 10. and 110. 7. Isa. 53. 10. 11. 12., and to shew that there was sufficiencie of merit and satisfaction in his death Rom. 4. 25. 1 Cor. 15 17..

div.head: Q. Open this last a little more plainely.
div.p: A. When a suretie apprehended and Iaid in prison hath fully discharged the debt, it is meete that then he should be released, and when he is released, it appeareth thereby that the debt is fully paid: so when Christ had fully satisfied for our sinnes, it was meete he should be released from death, and being so released it appeareth thereby that satisfaction for our sinnes was fully made.

div.head: Q. What other ends were there of the Resurrection of Christ?
div.p: A. He rose that he might have Lordship and Dominion over quicke and dead Rom. 14. 9. 10. Phil. 2. 8, 9. 10., which he had duely purchased by his suffering.

div.head: Q. Could Christ have performed the office whereto he was appointed, if he had not risen from the dead?
div.p: A. That may be another end of his Resurrection, namely that he might performe the office of an eternall Priest, and Prophet and King unto his People, which he could not have done if he had still remained under the power and Dominion of Death.

div.head: Q. What are the benefits of Christs Resurrection?
div.p: Hereby believers may be assured of their Iustification from all their sinnes Rom. 4. 25. 1 Cor. 15. 17. 1 Pet. 3. 21., of their spirituall rising to newnesse of life 1 Pet. 1. 3. Rom. 6. 4. Eph. 2. 5. 6. Col. 2. 12. and 31., and of their Resurrection to glorie at their last day 1 Cor. 15. 20, 21, 22. Rom. 8. 11. 2 Cor. 4 14..

div.head: CHAP. 21. Of Christs Ascention into Heaven.
Q WHen Christ was risen from the dead, did he still continue upon earth?
div.p: A. No, but after a time he left this world, and ascended into heaven Iohn 16 28.

div.head: Q What was the place from whence he did ascend?
div.p: A. In generall from this world, and in speciall from the mount of Olives neere unto Ierusalem Acts 1. 12.

div.head: Q What was the place to which he did ascend?
div.p: A. The third heaven, farre above this earth, and all these inferior and visible heavens. Mark 16. 19. Luk. 24. 51. Act. 1. 11. Ioh. 14. 1. 2. Eph. 4. 10.

div.head: Q. Was this ascention of Christ a true and reall mutation and change of place, or onely a change of his Estate?
div.p: A. Though Christ in respect of his Godhead be everywhere present Ioh. 3. 13., and in respect of the power and comfort of his spirit be present with all his saints upon earth Mat. 18. 20. and 28. 20. and Rev. 2. 1.; yet his ascention into heaven was such a true and reall change of place, that in respect of his bodily presence he is now no more upon earth, but in heaven Ioh. 16 28. Mat. 26. 11. Act. 3. 21.,

div.head: Q. What was the efficient cause of Christ ascention?
div.p: A. The power of the father, in respect whereof he is said to be received or taken up Mark. 16. 19. Act. 1. 2. 9. 11.; and his owne Almighty power, in respect of which he is said to ascend, or goe up Eph. 4. 10..

div.head: Q. When was the time of this ascention?
div.p: A. Forty dayes after his Resurrection from the dead Act. 1. 3.

div.head: Q. Why did he ascend no sooner?
div.p: A. Because he would first sufficiently confirme the faith of the disciples concerning his resurrection, and fully instruct them in the things pertayning to the kingdom of God. Acts 1. 3.

div.head: Q. Why did he stay upon earth no Longer?
div.p: A. To shew that it was not an earthly life, which he now affected or minded.

div.head: Q. Who were witnesses of his Ascention?
div.p: A. The disciples who were with him at that time upon the mount of Olives, and certaine Angel which then appeared. Acts 1. 9. 10. 11.

div.head: Q. For what end did Christ ascend into heaven?
div.p: A. That he might fulfill the scripture Luk 24. 44. Psal. 68. 18., and fully performe his office Heb. 6. 20. and 7. 26. and 8. 4., and take possession of the glory that was due unto him Luk. 24. 26..

div.head: Q. What else were the ends and fruits of his ascention?
div.p: A. The leading of Captivity Captive Psa. 68. 18., the giving of gifts unto men Eph. 4. 8. 11., the pouring out of his spirit upon his people Iohn 14. 16, 17. & 16. 7. Acts 2. 33., and preparing a place for them Iohn 14. 2. 3..

div.head: CHAP. 22. Of Christs sitting at the right hand of God, and his returne to the last judgement.
Q: BEsides the Resurrection and ascention of Christ, what further degree is there of his exaltation?
div.p: A. His sitting at the right hand of God Psal. 110. 1. Mark. 16. 19. Eph. 1. 20. Col. 3. 1. Heb. 1. 3, 13. and 8, 1. and 10. 12, 13.

div.head: Q. VVhat are we to understand by Christs sitting at the right hand of God?
div.p: A. That fulnesse of excellent majestie and glorious Dominion whereto he is now advanced, farre above the most glorious Angels and every other creature, Eph: 1. 20, 21, 22. Heb. 1. 13.

div.head: Q. But divine dominion and soveraignty over all Creatures belonging to the father and to the holy Ghost, why is this peculiarly ascribed unto Christ?
div.p: A. Not in respect of right but the actuall and immediate exercise thereof; for the former belong ing to all the divine persons, this latter is now peculiarly committed unto Christ: Ioh. 5. 22. 27. Act 10. 42. and 17. 31.

div.head: Q. VVho gave Christ this great authority thus to sit at the right hand of God?
div.p: A. He did not come unto it by any unjust usurpation, but it was given unto him by God. Eph. 1. 20. Phil. 2. 10. Iohn 5. 22. 27. and 17. 2.

div.head: Q. And why did God give this great advancement unto Christ?
div.p: A. Because the sonne did voluntarily humble himselfe to the greatest degree of obedience and humiliation; therefore the father gave unto him this exaltation and advancement, as a reward and recompence of that his humiliation, Phil. 2. 10. 11. Isa. 5. 3. 12.

div.head: Q. Doth Christ sit at the right hand of God in respect of his divine nature onely or in regard of his manhood also?
div.p: A. This dignity belongs to Christ as God and man in one person, and not in respect of one of his natures alone.

div.head: Q. How may that appeare?
div.p: A. Because it is given to him immediately upon his Ascention into heaven 1 Pet. 3. 22., and is to be exercised by him both as Davids Lord Psa. 110 1., and also as he is the sonne of man Ioh. 5. 27..

div.head: Q. How long shall this sitting of Christ at Gods right hand continue?
div.p: A. Vntill all his enemies be made his footstoole Psa. 110. 1. 1. Cor. 15. 25?

div.head: Q. Shall it never cease and have an end?
div.p: A. If we speake of his reigning and ruling in a way and manner peculiar and appropriate to his person, so we may safely say that when all his enemies are put under his feet, then shalbe the end, when he shall deliver up the kingdome to the father, and himselfe be subject to him, 1 Cor. 15. 24, 25, 28.

div.head: Q. What shall be the last act of this glorious power and authority of Christ, and so the last degree of his exaltation?
div.p: A. His returne to Iudgement at the last day, when he shall come a second time into this world with unspeakable majestie and glory, to judge the Quick and dead 2 Tim: 4. 1. Act. 10. 42. and 17, 31. and Mat. 25. 31. and 26. 64. & 2 Thes. 1. 7, 8, 9.

div.head: CHAP. 23. Of faith and union with Christ.
Q. YOu have spoken of the person, Offices and actions of Christ; you are now to shew the benefits that come by Christ, and how we are made partakers of Christ and of his benefits?
div.p: A. We are made partakers of Christ and all his benefits by faith alone, Iohn 1. 12. and 3. 16, 18, 36. and 20. 31. Eph. 3. 17. and Act. 16. 31.

div.head: Q. What meane you by faith?
div.p: A. That grace of the spirit whereby we receive Christ, which is wrought in our hearts in our effectuall calling?

div.head: Q How is faith wrought in effectuall callings?
div.p: A. Effectuall calling consists of two parts, the offer of Christ to the soule, and the soule excepting of that offer or the call of God when he calls the soule to come to Christ, and the answere of the soule unto that call Ier. 3. 22. Ioh. 6. 44, 45. and 10. 16. Isa. 55. 5.: now this latter is nothing else but faith:

div.head: Q. How is faith wrought in us?
div.p: A. Not by any power of our owne freewill Iohn 6. 44., or meerely by morall perswasion Act. 13. 41.; for we are dead in sinnes and treepasses Eph: 2: 1:.

div.head: Q. How then is it wrought?
div.p: A. By the almighty power of the spirit of God as the author of it Acts 16, 14. Phil. 1. 29. 2 Cor. 4, 13. Rom. 15. 13.; and by the word as the instrument thereof Rom. 10. 14, 17. Act. 15. 7.,

div.head: Q. How doth the word worke faith?
div.p: A. The Law prepareth for it Gal. 3. 24. Rom. 10. 4., by convincing the soule of sinne Rom. 3. 20. and 7, 9, 10., and terrifying for the same Rom. 4. 15: Exod. 20. 18, 19., through the worke of the spirit of bondage Rom. 8. 15.:

div.head: Q. And what doth the Gospel?
div.p: A. It presents the excellency and worth of Christ as an onely and alsufficient saviour Ioh. 3. 16. Act. 13, 38. 39. 1 Tim. 1. 15.; but withall convincing the soule of its great sinne in not beleeving in Christ Ioh. 16. 9., of its utter insufficiency to come to him Ioh. 6. 44., and its great unworthynesse Luk. 3. 4, 5. and 15, 17, 18, 19. to have any part or portion in him.

div.head: Q. What followeth hereupon?
div.p:
A. Hereby the soule feeling it selfe to be utterly
lost is further and more kindely broken and humbled, Luke 19. 10. Isa. 61, 1, 2, 3. Math. 11. 20. Zac: 12. 10.

div.head: Q What else is done by the Gospell in the working of faith?
div.p: A. It sweetly encourageth poore lost soules to come to Jesus Christ Mat: 11. 28. Ioh: 6. 37. Isa. 55. 1. 2. • 2 Cor: 5. 20., and enableth them so to doe, rowling and resting themselves upon him Iohn 6. 44, 45 Ier. 3. 22. Iohn 13. 15. Rom. 1. 16., by the helpe of the spirit of grace Zac. 12. 10., which is ministred thereby Gal. 3. 2. 2 Cor. 3. 8.,

div.head: Q It seemes then you make Christ the object of faith?
div.p: A. Yea; not onely the whole truth of God Act. 24. 14., but specially Christ Jesus as he is set forth in the promises of the gospel, is the obiect of saving faith Ioh. 3. 16. Act. 16. 31.,

div.head: Q. Wherein doth the nature of this faith consist?
div.p: A. Not onely in knowledge of the revealed will of God Rom. 10. 8, 14; 15.; and in assent to the truth thereof Act. 24. 14.; for so much may be found in devils Iam. 2. 19. Mark. 1. 24..

div.head: Q. What is there more then this in saving faith?
div.p: A. There is also a comming unto Iesus Christ Ioh. 6. 35. 44, 45, 65., with affiance Eph. 1. 12. 2 Tim. 1. 12. Isa. 50. 10., and reliance upon him Cant. 8. 5.,

div.head: Q. What is the subject in whom this faith is wrought?
div.p: A. This faith is not wrought in any reprobate but only in the elect Rom. 8. 30. Act. 13. 48. Ioh. 6, 37. and 10. 26.; and not onely in the understanding, or only in the will but in the whole heart Rom: 10. 10. Act. 8, 37..

div.head: Q. And what an heart is it in whom this faith is wrought?
div.p: A. Onely the heart of such an one as is now a poore, lost and broken-hearted sinner: Math. 9. 12, and 11, 28. Luke 19. 10. and 3. 4, 5, 6.

div.head: Q. VVhy say you so?
div.p: A. Because till the heart be thus prepared, men will never come to Christ Iohn 5. 40. Rom: 10. 3. Ier. 2. 31, 36. Luke 15. 16., nor can they truly beleeve on him Iohn 5 44.,

div.head: Q. VVhat thinke you then of those who professe themselves to be true beleevers, and yet were never in any measure thus prepared and humbled?
div.p: A. The case of such professors is very dangerous.

div.head: Q. Why say you so?
div.p:
A. Because the fallow ground of their hearts being never broken up, they doe but sow among thornes Ier. 4. 3. 4., & so the stoninesse of their hearts not being removed by any sound & thorough worke of contrition and humiliation, therfore though they may for a time receive the word with joy, and beleeve for a season, yet they are like to be
but temporary beleevers, and in time of temptation fall away Matth. 1. 3. 5, 6, 20, 21. Luk. 8. 6, 13.,

div.head: Q. You have shewed the cause, and the object, the nature and subject of faith; tell me now what are the principall effects of faith?
div.p: A. Hereby we have union with Christ himselfe Iohn 12. Eph. 3. 17., and so communion with him in all the benefits which he hath purchased for the Elect Rom. 8. 32. 1 Cor. 3 22..

div.head: Q. What understand you by union with Christ?
div.p: A. That spirituall conjunction 1 Cor 6. 17. betweene Christ and the beleever whereby the beleever hath possesion of Christ as his owne 1 Ioh. 5. 12. Cant. 2. 16., dwelling in Christ Rom. 16. 7. 2 Cor: 5. 17., and Christ in him Eph. 3. 17. Ioh. 6. 56:, and is made one spirit with him 1 Cor. 6. 17. Ioh. 17. 21..

div.head: Q. By what comparisons or similitudes is this union expressed in Scripture?
div.p: A. It is expressed by that union that is between the husband and wife Eph. 5. 23., the vine and the branches Ioh. 15. 4. 5., and the head and the members Col. 2. 19. Eph. 4. 16. 1 Cor. 12. 12..

div.head: Q. What benefit comes to beleevers by meanes of this their union with Christ?
div.p:
A. Being one with Christ, therefore Christ will be sure to take all their Injuries and afflictions as if they were his owne Act. 9. 4. 5. Math. 25. 40. 45., will free them
from condemnation Rom. 8. 1., and afford unto them communion with him in all his benefits 1 Cor. 3. 22. 23.,

div.head: Q. What are those Benefits of Christ wherein beleevers have communion with him by vertue of this their union?
div.p: A. Some of the principal are Justification Rom. 3. 24. Acts 13. 39., Adoption Iohn 1. 12. Gal. 3. 26., and Sanctification 1 Cor. 1. 30. and 6. 11. Eph: 5. 26., besides which if God give us Christ, he will with him freely give us all things also Rom: 8: 32..

div.head: CHAP. 24. Of Justification & of Adoption.
Q LEt us come to the first of these benefits whih is our justification; and first tell me what is the meaning of the word to justifie?
div.p: A. It doth not signifie to make an unjust man just by changing his qualities; for then it were all one with sanctification from which it is distinct 1 Cor 6. 1. 1.

div.head: Q. What then doth it signifie?
div.p: A. To Iustifie is frequently opposed to condenme Prov. 17. 15. Dent. 25. 1. Mat. 12. 37. Rom. 8. 33., and therefore it doth properly signifie to acquit from blame and punishment

div.head: Q. What is the cause of our justification.
div.p: A. The impulsive cause that moveth God to justifie a sinner is nothing else but his free grace: Rom. 3 24. Tit 3. 7.

div.head: Q. VVhat is that for which God doth justifie?
div.p: A. God doth not justifie us without righteousnesse; for then how should God be just Exod. 34. 7. Rom. 2. 2. Gen. 18. 25. Prov 17. 15.? but he justifieth us by and for a righteousnesse which is most exact and perfect.

div.head: Q. What is that perfect righteousnesse?
div.p: A. Not our own righteousnesse in obedience to the Law Rom. 3. 2c. Gal. 3. 11. & 2. 16. Psal. 143. 2. Phil. 3. 9., for that is most imperfect Isai 64. 6. Psal. 130. 3.

div.head: Q. What righteousnesse is it then?
div.p: A. That perfect righteousnesse whereby we are justified is that righteousnesse which was wrought by Christ, and inherent in his person, Isai 45. 24, 25. Ier. 23. 6. 1 Cor. 1. 30. 2 Cor. 5. 21. Rom. 5. 18, 19.

div.head: Q. How comes the righteousnesse of Christ to be ours, that we may be justified thereby?
Q. Open this a little further, how faith is considered when we are said to be justified by faith?
div.p: A. Faith is not considered in justification properly, as if the very act of believing were the matter of our righteousnesse; neither doth it iustifie as a work or vertue in us by any merit of it selfe.

div.head: Q. Why may not faith be considered in our justification as a work or vertue in us?
div.p: A. Because all workes of ours are excluded from being any cause or matter of our justification Rom. 3. 28. Gal. 2 16. Phil. 39.; and therefore if faith were so considered, it must then be excluded also;

div.head: Q. How then is faith considered when we are said to be justified by faith?
div.p: A. Onely relatively in respect of the object of it, which is Jesus Christ and his righteousnesse.

div.head: Q. Faith being not considered in our justification properly as a worke or vertue in us, it must needs then be considered relatively in respect of Christ the object of it; but how may the truth of this yet further appeare?
div.p: A. As the Scripture saith we are justified by faith, so it also saith Christ is our righteousnesse Ier. 23. 6., and that we are justified by Christ Acts 13 39. 2 Cor. 5. 21..

div.head: Q. VVhat else may be said for the further clearing of this truth?
div.p: A. Sometimes this phrase, to be justified by faith, is expounded in the words immediately following, to be nothing else but to be justified by Christ, Gal. 2. 16. 17.

div.head: Q. VVhat are the parts of justification?
div.p:
A. Justification is onely one benefit of God vouchsafed to believers; but there are two parts thereof inseparably conjoyned, namely, forgivenesse
of sinnes through the sufferings of Christ, and accounting a man just and righteous through the righteousnesse of Christ imputed to him.

div.head: Q. VVhat is the object of justification, the persons whom God doth justifie?
div.p: A. Onely the Elect Rom. 8. 30. Isai 45. 25., being by nature and in themselves sinners and ungodly Rom. 5. 4, 5. & 5. 10., but called by grace to be true believers in Christ Rom. 8. 30 Gal. 2. 16. Rom. 3. 30..

div.head: Q. What is Adoption?
div.p: A. An act of Gods free grace 1 Iohn 31., whereby the Elect Eph. 1. 5. being in themselves aliens & strangers Eph. 2. 19. from God, are upon their believing in Christ 2 Cor. 6. 17, 18. Iohn 1. 12. Gal. 3. 26. admitted for Christs sake Iohn 1. 12. Gal. 4. 4, 5., on whom they doe believe, into the houshold of God, and to the dignity and priviledge of his children Eph. 2 12. 2 Cor. 6. 18..

div.head: Q What are the benefits of this adoption?
div.p: A. By means hereof believers are brethren to Christ Jesus Rom. 8. 29. Heb. 2. 11, 12. Iohn 20. 17., have title to the heavenly inheritance Rom 8. 17. and have liberty and boldnesse to make their requests to God Gal 4. 6. Rom. 8. 15., as to a most gracious and loving father, with great assurance to be heard Matth. 7. 9, 10, 11..

div.head: CHAP. 25. Of Sanctification, and the difference between it and Justification; and of foure other benefits of Christ to believers.
Q. SAnctification being another of those benefits that come by Christ, and our union with Christ, tell me first of all what Sanctification is?
div.p: A. It is a true and reall change 1 Cor. 6. 11. 2 Cor. 5. 17., wrought by the Spirit of God 1 Thess. 5. 23. 2 Thess. 2. 13., in the Elect Isai 4. 5. Eph. 1. 4., now believing on Christ Acts 15. 9. & 26. 18.: whereby the whole man 1 Thes. 5. 23. is changed and altered from the turpitude and filthinesse of sinne 2 Cor. 7. 1. Eph. 4. 22, 24. Rom. 6. 3, 4, 11., to the purity of the Image of God.

div.head: Q. VVhat difference is there between the former benefit▪ to wit Iustification, and this of Sanctification?
div.p: A. The materiall cause of the one is the righteousnesse of Christ without us, imputed to us Ier. 236. 2 Cor. 5. 21. Rom. 46: but the materiall cause of the other is a body of divine graces and qualities infused into the soule, created in us 2 Pet. 14. Gal. 5. 22..

div.head: Q. How doe they differ in respect of their formall causes?
div.p:
A. The formall cause of justification is the pronouncing of the sentence of absolution, and accepting a mans person for righteous: the formall
cause of Sanctification is the restoring o Gods Image into the soule, by putting off the old man, and putting on the new, Ephes. 4. 22, 23, 24

div.head: Q. How else doe they differ?
div.p: A. Justification makes no reall change in the soule, as when the Judge acquits a man, but makes him never a whit the more honest then before; but Sanctification makes a great change in the soule from sinne and corruption unto purity and holinesse, Rom. 6. 17. 1 Tim. 1. 13. 1 Cor. 6. 11.

div.head: Q. What may be a fourth difference?
div.p: A. Justification is perfect at the first, as one individuall act; but Sanctification is a graduall work, imperfect at the first, and growing by degrees.

div.head: Q. Why doe you say that Iustification is perfect at the first?
div.p: A. Not in respect of the sense and feeling, and assurance of it, for these may increase and grow daily, and are therefore daily to be prayed for, Mat. 6. 12. Luke 17. 5.

div.head: Q. How then is justification perfect at the first?
div.p: A. In respect of the matter whereby we are justified, which is the imputed righteousnesse of Christ, which is so perfect that a man can never have more all the daies of his life, though he should live as long as ever any did.

div.head: Q. Is not Sanctification also perfect at the first?
div.p: A. Farre from it; for the honest men upon earth have been sensible of such imperfection Rom. 7. 14, 15, 18, 19, 21, 23. Phil. 3. 12, 13. Isai 6. 5. in their Sanctification, that they durst not stand to be justified before God thereby Psal. 130. 3. & 143. 2. Iob 9. 2, 3, 14, 15, 20, 21..

div.head: Q. VVhat proceeds from this imperfection of Sanctification?
div.p: A. A continuall combat between corruption and grace in the sanctified soule, Gal. 5. 17. Rom. 7.

div.head: Q. And what else?
div.p: A. A continuall exercise of repentance, and of fleeing to the grace of God in Christ Jesus, Rom. 7. 24, 25.

div.head: Q. Iustification, Adoption, and Sanctification are excellent benefits that come to believers through Christ; tell me what other benefits do accompany or flow from these?
div.p: A. In this life there doth accompany or flow from them assurance of Gods love, lively hope, and expectation of glory, peace of conscience, and joy in the holy Ghost, Rom. 5. 1, 2, 5. & 14. 17. Tit. 2. 13.

div.head: Q. If these things be vouchsafed to believers in this life, what shall they have in the life to come?
div.p: A. Unspeakable glory and happinesse in the immediate fruition of communion with God and Christ unto all eternity, Col. 3. 4. 1 Iohn 3. 2. Heb. 12. 23. 1 Cor. 15. 28.

div.head: Q But may not a true believer lose his faith, and so lose all these benefits that come by faith in this life, and fall short of eternall glory in the life to come?
div.p: A. If he should finally lose his faith, it would be so indeed; but God that of his grace hath wrought this faith in him, will preserve and perfect the same untill the day of Christ, Phil. 1. 6. 1 Cor. 1. 8.

div.head: Q. Doe you mean then that a true believer can never totally nor finally fall away, but shall persevere in grace unto the end?
div.p: A. Yea, I mean so indeed; this perseverance of believers in the state of grace being plainly and plenteously taught in the holy Scriptures, 1 Pet. 1. 5. Luke 22. 31, 32. Iohn 17. 20, 21. & 10. 28. Mat. 16. 18. Ier. 3 • . 40.

div.head: CHAP. 26. Of the necessity of faith, its imperfection at the first, and the means whereby it may be increased: Of hearing the word, and of Baptisme and the Lords Supper.
Q. YOu have shewed many excellent benefits that come by faith; but whether is faith of such necessity that these things cannot be without it?
div.p: A. Such is the necessity of this grace of faith, that in respect of the usuall way of Gods dispensation, there is no hope nor possibility that a man should escape wrath or attaine happinesse in this or in another world without faith, Iohn 3. 18 36. Mark 16. 16. Heb. 11. 6.

div.head: Q. Faith then is very profitable and necessary; but whether is it perfect at the first, or groweth by degrees?
div.p: A. The best faith is imperfect in this life 1 Cor. 13. 9, 12. 2 Thes. 1. 3. with 1 Thes. 3. 10., and is usually little at the first Mat. 8. 26. & 12. 20., increasing and growing by degrees unto more perfection Rom. 1. 17. 2 Thes. 1. 3. Iob 17. 9..

div.head: Q. VVhat are the ordinary and usuall means for increasing of faith?
div.p: A. Hearing the word 1 Pet. 2. 2. Eph. 4 12. Pro. 1. 5. & 9. 9., Communion of Saints Psa. 92. 13 & 65. 4. 1 Thes. 5. 11., receiving of Sacraments Rom. 4. 11. 1 Cor. 10 16., prayer Mark 9. 24. Luke 17. 5., reading Acts 17. 11, 12., meditation Psa. 119. 99. and conference.

div.head: Q. When must we heare the word?
div.p: A. The usuall and ordinary time is on the Lords day Acts 13. 14, 15, 16, 44. & 20. 7. & Acts 15. 21. & Luke 4. 16., and other times also 2 Tim 4. 2. Pre. 8. 34. Luke 10. 39, 40, 41, 42. are not to be neglected, when God gives such opportunity.

div.head: Q VVhat rules must be observed before we come to heare the word that we may get profit thereby?
div.p:
A. We must lay aside our sinnes 1 Pet. 2. 1, 2. Iam. 1. 21., seriously consider the weightinesse of the work we goe about Eccl. 5. 1, 2., resolve to obey whatsoever shall be
shewed to be the will of God Deut. 5. 27, 28, 29. Ier. 42. 5, 6., and pray to him that he would teach us to profit Isay 48. 17. Acts 16. 14..

div.head: Q. VVhat rules must be observed in hearing?
div.p: A. Reverent attention Nehem. 8. 3. Luke 4. 20. Acts 10. 33., with spirituall affections Mat. 13. 20. Luke 24. 32., giving credit to the truth Heb. 4. 2. 1 Thes. 1. 5., and applying the word unto our selves 2 Cor. 7. 1. Heb. 13. 5, 6. Psal. 40. 7..

div.head: Q VVhat must we observe after we haue heard?
div.p: A. We must meditate of the same afterward Deut. 11. 18. Luke 2. 19. 51. Psalm 119. 97., confer of it with others Deut. 6. 7. Luke 2. 15. & 24. 32., pray to God for a blessing 1 Chro. 29. 18. 1 Cor. 3. 6, 7., and set upon the practice of what is required Iam. 1. 22, 23, 24, 25. Mat. 7. 24, 26. Ezek. 33. 31, 32..

div.head: Q. VVhat is the generall nature of Sacraments?
div.p: A. They are divine instructions annexed to the word, for the teaching of Spirituall things, Gen. 17. Exod. 12. Mat. 26.

div.head: Q. Who is the Author of Sacraments?
div.p: A. Onely God Exod. 20. 4 Mat. 17. 5. & 23. 8., who is the Author of those Spirituall blessings and duties that are taught thereby.

div.head: Q VVhat are the parts of a Sacrament?
div.p: A. Two: an outward and visible signe, and an inward and Spirituall blessing, which is the thing signified.

div.head: Q. Who are to receive the Sacraments?
div.p: A. The faithfull members of some visible Church, and their seed, Gen. 17. 10, 11. Acts 2. 39.

div.head: Q. VVhat is the proper effect and use of a Sacrament?
div.p: A. To be a signe and seale of the covenant between God and his people, and of those spirituall blessings which are promised therein, Gen. 17. 10, 11. Rom. 4. 11. Exod. 12. Mat. 26.

div.head: Q. How many Sacraments are there?
div.p: A. In the New Testament onely two: Baptisme and the Lords Supper, Mat. 28. 19. & 26. 26, &c.

div.head: Q. VVhat is the outward signe or part in Baptisme?
div.p: A. Water Acts 8. 36. & 10. 47., and washing therewith Eph. 5. 26, in the name of the Father, Sonne, and Holy Ghost Mat. 28 19..

div.head: Q. What is the thing signified?
div.p: A. Union with Christ Rom 6 3. Gal. 3. 27. 1 Cor. 12. 13., and forgivenesse of sinnes Acts 2. 38. Mark 1. 4., with sanctification in the mortifying of corruption, and quickning the soule to newnesse▪ of life Tit. 3. 5. Eph. 5. 26. Rom. 3. 4..

div.head: Q. Who ought to be baptized?
div.p:
A. Men of yeeres when once they are converted to the faith, and joyned to the Churchg Acts 8. 37. & 16. 15, 36. & 8. 12.; and such infants whose parents, both or one of
them are to be converted and joyned Acts 2. 39 Gen. 17. 12. 1 Cor. 7. 14..

div.head: Q. Who is the author of the Lords Supper?
div.p: A. The Lord Jesus in the same night in which he was betrayed when he was about to lay down his life, which was the greatest act of love that ever was, 1 Cor. 11. 23, 24.

div.head: Q. VVhat is the outward signe in the Lords Supper?
div.p: A. Bread and Wine with the actions pertaining to them, which are breaking and pouring out, giving and receiving, eating and drinking, Mat. 26. 26. 1 Cor. 11. 24, 25, &c.

div.head: Q VVhat is the spirituall blessing, or thing signified?
div.p: A. The generall sum thereof is Christ himselfe, and our communion with him, and withall the benefits of his passion, Mat. 26. 26, &c. 1 Cor. 10 16.

div.head: Q. What are the things signified more particularly?
div.p: A. The passion of Christ, and his sacrifice upon the Crosse, consisting in the crucifying of his body, and shedding of his blood, 1 Cor. 11. 26.

div.head: Q. What else?
div.p: A. The action of God the father giving Iohn 3. 16. Rom. 8. 32. Christ for and to the elect, with the action of Christ giving himselfe Eph. 5. 2. Iohn 17. 19. to death, and likewise giving himselfe to the soules of the faithfull.

div.head: Q. What is the third thing signified in the Lords Supper?
div.p: A. The act of faith, receiving Christ and feeding on him spiritually Iohn 1. 12. and Eph. 3. 17. Iohn 6. 35., so as to grow unto more communion with his 1 Cor. 10. 16. body and blood, and spirituall strength of grace thereby

div.head: Q. Who ought to receive the Lords Supper?
div.p: A. Such members of the Church as are endewed with knowledge Exod. 12. 26, 27. & 1 Cor. 11. 28, 29. spirituall affections Zac. 12. 10. Isai 55. 1. Rev. 22. 17. Iohn 7. 37., faith Heb. 11. 6. Iohn 6. 35. repentance Psal. 26. 6. Hag. 2. 12, 13., love Mat. 5. 23, 24. 1 Cor. 10. 17., and thankfulnesse 1 Cor. 11. 25, 26..

div.head: CHAP. 27. Of prayer, and some other means of increasing faith.
Q. WHat is the generall nature of prayer?
div.p: A. Not onely a wish or desire after this, or that; for a man may have so much and never pray, Iam. 4. 2.

div.head: Q. VVhat is it then?
div.p: A. Prayer is an opening of the desire of the heart before God Psa. 25. 1. 1 Sam. 1. 13, whether it be by ffighes and groanes Rom. 8. 26, 27., or by words Hos. 14. 2. Psa. 5. 1., and other means Iohn 17. 1. Lam. 3. 43. Ps. 6. 8 & 142. 2..

div.head: Q To whom must we pray?
div.p: A. To him that knoweth the heart 1 Kings 8. 39., and is almighty, and so able to help Heb. 5. 7. Gen. 17. 1., to him that is to be worshipped Mat. 4. 10, and believed in Rom. 10. 14., which is none but God.

div.head: Q. Whether must we pray to God directly and immediately, or through a Mediator?
div.p: A. Onely through the mediation of Jesus Christ, Iohn 146. & 16. 23. 1 Tim. 2. 5. Heb. 7. 25.

div.head: Q. What are the parts of prayer?
div.p: A. Petition and Thanksgiving, Phil. 4. 6. 1 Thess. 5. 17, 11.

div.head: Q. What is Petition?
div.p: A. A prayer wherein we aske the preventing or removing of things hurtfull, and the bestowing of things needfull, Mat 7. 7, 8, 9, 10.

div.head: Q What is Thanksgiving?
div.p: A. A prayer wherein we desire that honour and glory may be given to God for what we have received Psa. 50. 15., or do believe we shall receive hereafter 2 Sam. 7. 18, 19..

div.head: Q. Whether is not confession of our sinnes and miseries, and vows and promises unto God, parts of prayer?
div.p: A. They may be called adjuncts of prayer, because they are to be expressed or understood in every prayer.

div.head: Q. How may that appeare?
div.p:
A. By this, because to come to God for mercy
without an acknowledgement of our unworthinesse and misery, and to desire him to perform what he requires of us, is little better then a mocking of God.

div.head: Q. Are there any for whom we must not pray?
div.p: A. Yes; we must not pray for the dead, because we cannot do it of faith, as having neither precept nor example, nor any good warrant for it in the world, Rom. 14. 23.

div.head: Q. VVhy else may we not pray for the dead?
div.p: A. Because such prayers cannot availe at all, but are altogether vain, 1 Pet. 3. 19. Heb. 9. 27.

div.head: Q. For whom else must we not pray?
div.p: A. We must not pray for the salvation of all men living universally, for that is contrary to the revealed will of God Mat. 7. 13, 14.; nor for any in particular that have sinned the sinne against the Holy Ghost 1 Iohn 5. 16..

div.head: Q. For whom then must we pray?
div.p: A. For all other sorts of men now living 1 Tim. 2. 1, 2., both our selves and others Mat. 6. 9. Iam. 5. 16., whether they be friends or enemies Mat. 5. 44. Luke 23. 34. Acts 7. 60., and for some that shall live hereafter Iohn 17. 20..

div.head: Q. Is there any rule of direction according to which we ought to frame our prayers?
div.p: A. Yes, the whole will of God revealed for this purpose in the word 1 Iohn 5. 14., and that pattern of prayer given by Christ unto his Disciples Mat. 6. 9..

div.head: Q. Seeing God knoweth all our wants afore we pray, and hath determined with himselfe what he will doe for us, wherefore then should we pray?
div.p: A. Not to inform him, as if he were ignorant of our estates, for he understandeth our thoughts afarre off Psal. 139. 2. nor to change his minde, for his purpose is unchangeable Iam. 1. 17. Psal. 33 11..

div.head: Q. Why then?
div.p: A. We are therefore to pray, because God hath appointed prayer to be the way and means Ezek. 36. 37. 2 Sam. 7. 27. whereby he will accomplish that which he hath purposed to doe for us.

div.head: Q. How must we pray that we may be accepted?
div.p: A. The persons praying must be righteous Iohn 9: 31. humble Psal. 10. 17. and upright Pro. 15. 8. and Psal. 66. 18. and the matter of prayer must be something lawfull and promised Mat. 20. 22, 23..

div.head: Q. And what must be the manner of praying, and the end aymed at therein?
div.p: A. The manner must be in sense and feeling of our wants Isai 41. 17.; with faith Iam. 1. 6, 7. Mat. 21. 22., fervency Iam. 5. 16., and perseverance Luke 18. 12. &; and the end must not be that we may consume it upon our lusts, but for the glory of God Iam. 4. 3..

div.head: Q. What other means are there for the increasing of faith?
div.p: A. Diligent reading of the holy Scriptures Iohn 5. 39. Acts 17. 11., and serious meditation therein Psal. 1. 2. & 119. 97., with frequent and holy conference with others Deut. 6. 7. Mal. 3. 16. Luke 24. 32.

div.head: CHAP. 28. Of the Church Catholike or Mysticall, and the Difference between it and particular instituted Churches.
Q. WHo is the subject of Redemption, or of all that deliverance obtained by Christ?
div.p: A. Not the blessed Angels, because having never fallen they needed no Redeemer, nor all the race of mankind, for Christ would not pray for the world, Iohn 17. 9.

div.head: Q. Who then were redeemed by Christ?
div.p: A. He gave himselfe for none others but only for his Church, Eph. 5. 25. Acts 20. 28. Iohn 10. 15. & 11. 52.

div.head: Q. What is meant by the Church in the holy Scriptures?
div.p: A. It is usually taken in Scripture, either for the Catholique Church Col. 1. 18. Eph. 1. 22, 23. Heb. 12. 23. which is called the Church mysticall, or else it is taken for the Church instituted, or particular Churches 1 Cor. 11. 16. & 14. 23, 33. & 7. 17. Rev. 1. 4. & 2. 23..

div.head: Q. What is the difference between the catholike, universall and mysticall Church, and the instituted or particular churches?
div.p: A. They differ in their number; for the catholike Church is but one Church, one body Eph. 1. 22, 23. and 4. 4. but of the other sort in the dayes of the new Testament there are many Churches Rom. 16. 4. 1 Cor. 14. 33. & 7. 17. Rev. 1. 4. and 2. 23:.

div.head: Q Wherein do they differ in respect of the matter?
div.p: A. The Catholike Church hath none in it but Saints, and all true beleevers are in it e: but particular Churches have some times many wolves within Mat. 13. 25, 27. Iude. 4. Act. 20. 29, 30. Rev. 2. 14, 15, 20., and many sheepe without Isa. 56. 3. Ioh. 10. 16., though it ought not so to be: Eph. 5. 23, 25, 26, 27. Heb. 12. 23.

div.head: Q. What is a third defference betweene them?
div.p: A. The forme which constitutes the Catholike Church is their union which Christ by faith Eph. 1. 10. 2 Pet. 1. 1. but the forme of the other is the bond of an holy covenant Deut. 29. 10, 11, 12, 13. Ezek 20. 37. Ier. 50. 4, 5., to walk together in all the waies of Christ.

div.head: Q. Is there not some difference between them in regard of place?
div.p:
A. Yes, for some parts and members of the Catholike Church are now in heaven, and the rest shall all come thither in Gods appointed time Eph. 1. 10. and 3. 15. Col. 1. 20.; but the members of particular or instituted Churches are all of them upon the earth for
the present, and some of them must never come in heaven Mat. 22. 14..

div.head: Q. What may be a fifth difference?
div.p: A. Whereas particular churches are visible to themselves and others also, especially in times of peare Mat. 18. 17. Isa. 2. 2, 3. Rev. 11. 19., the Catholike church is properly a Church invisible.

div.head: Q How is that proved, that the Catholike Church is invisible?
div.p: A. Because some parts thereof are now in heaven: and those that are on earth never were nor will be all together that they might be seen.

div.head: Q. What may be a further proofe hereof?
div.p: A. Their union whith Christ wich is the form of that Church, is knowne onely unto God.

div.head: Q Name a sixth difference?
div.p: A. The Catholike Church and all the members of it continue for ever Psal. 125. 1 Ioh. 10. 28. and 1 Ioh. 2. 19.; but particular churches! by persecutions and corruptions may come to be utterly dissolved and extinct Rev. 2. 5. Rom. 11. 22..

div.head: Q. What is a last difference betweene them?
div.p: A. The ordinary ministery appointed by christ is for the instituted and particular churches, but not for the church catholike as such, because that church hath no Pastor nor Bishop but Christ.

div.head: Q. How may this appeare that ministers are not ministers of the universall Church, but only of some particular congregation?
div.p: A. The church to whom the ministery belong is to chuse her owne ministers Act 1. 23. and 14. 23. and 6. 3, 5. but the unversall church never comes together to make any such choice:

div.head: Q. How else may this appeare?
div.p: A. There is no part of the church to which the ministery belongs, but it stands in need of ministers Eph. 4. 12, 13.. but a good part of the catholike Church is glorious in heaven with Christ, and therefore hath no such need

div.head: Q. What may be a third ground hereof?
div.p: A. The flock of God over which the Holy ghost: doth make men overseers, is such as may be attended and watched over; even the whole flocke and ministers thereof Acts 20. 28. 1 Peter 5. 2, 3.:

div.head: Q. And why may not the same be said of the Catholike Church?
div.p: A. Because that Church is so large that it is not possible for any man to attend it or watch over it.

div.head: Q. Is there any evill in it for one man to be a Bishop or minister to all Christians, where ever they be disposed of, and not onely to one congregation?
div.p:
A. Besides that such a man must needs neglect the greatest part of his charge, it is a great part of the usurpation of the Bishop of Rome, for
which he is truely called Antichrist, that he will take upon him to be universall Bishop 1 Thes. 2. 4. Rev. 13. 16, 17. over all the Christians in the world

div.head: Q Who is the head of the catholike church?
div.p: A. Onely Iesus Christ Eph. 1. 22. and 4. 15, 16. and 5. 23. Col. 1. 18., as giving influence of life, sense and motion to the same, as the head doth unto the body:

div.head: Q Who are the members of that church?
div.p: A. Only they and all they that are effectually called to be true beleevers in Christ: Rev. 17. 14. Iohn 15. 19.

div.head: Q. What are the parts of the Catholike church?
div.p: A. According to the degrees of communion which they have with Christ, so that church may be distinguished into that which is militant and that which is triumphant.

div.head: Q. VVhat is the church militant?
div.p: A. It is that part of the catholike Church which is warring and fighting here on earth against spirituall enemies, the divell, the world and the flesh. Eph. 6. 12. Phil. 1. 30. & 2 Cor. 10. 4. 1 Tim. 1. 18.

div.head: Q. And what is the Church Triumphant?
div.p: A. It is that part of the Catholike church which are now in heaven, gloriously triumphing over all those enemies which in this world they did conflict and combate withall. Eph. 4. 13. Heb. 12. 23. Eph. 5. 27.

div.head: CHAP. 29. Of the instituted Church, or perticular churches.
Q. WHat is the matter of particular or visible churches?
div.p: A. By the appointment of Christ all churches ought to consist onely of true beleevers Isay 52. 1. and 60. 21. Ioel 3. 17. Rev. 21. 27. & 22. 15. Eph. 1. 1. Phil. 1. 1. and all that are true beleevers ought to joyn themselves unto some church Mat. 28. 20. and 6. 33. Cant. 1. 7, 8. Isay 2. 2, 3. Zech. 8. 23. Acts 2. 41, 42, and, 9. 26..

div.head: Q. If the matter of particular churches for the quality of it ought to be true beleevers in Christ, what ought to be the quantity thereof?
div.p: Q No more in number in the dayes of the new Testament, but onely so many as may ordinarily meet together in one congregation, Acts 2. 46. & 5. 12. & 3. 2. & 14. 27. & 15. 25. 1 Cor. 5. 4. and 11. 17, 18. and 14. 23.

div.head: Q. Is any thing else needfull to the being of a visible church but onely the matter above mentioned?
div.p: A. Timber and stones are not an house untill they be compacted and joyned together; and as the humane soule and body are not man, unlesse they be united; so beleevers are not a visible church, without some visible bond and union.

div.head: Q. And what is that bond that doth unite them?
div.p:
A. An holy agreement and covenant Deut. 29. 10, 11, 12, 13. Ezek. 20. 37. Ier. 50. 4, 5. zech. 11. 10, 14., with God and one another, to walke together in such
duties of worship to God and edification of one another as the Gospell of Christ requireth of all Churches and the members thereof:

div.head: Q. How many kinds of Churches are there?
div.p: A. The visible Church (if we speake of that which is truely so called) is one and the same in essence, from the beginning of the world to the end thereof; namely a company of people united together in the profession of the true religion.

div.head: Q. But may not the true church be some way distinguished?
div.p: A Yes; for there is the church of the old Testament, and the churches of the new: there are pure churches and churches that are corrupt; and besides these that are true, there are also some that are false Churches.

div.head: Q. What is the Church of the old Testament?
div.p: A A company of people united together in the profession of such a Religion, or faith, whereby men beleeved on Christ then to come.

div.head: Q. What is a Church of the new Testement?
div.p: A. A company of people united together in the profession of such a religion or faith whereby men beleeve on Christ already come.

div.head: Q What are pure churches and churches that are corrupt?
div.p:
A. A pure Church is such a church whose matter
forme, doctrine, worship, and ministery is accordding to the appointment of Christ in the word.

div.head: Q. And what is a corrupt Church?
div.p: A. Such an one as in the things last mentioned or in some of them doth swerve from the appointment of Christ, yet still holding the foundation of salvation.

div.head: Q. How if their swerving be such as overthroweth the foundation?
div.p: A. Then they cease to be a true church, and become either no church, or at the best a false church.

div.head: Q. What is a false church?
div.p: A. One that is so exceedingly corrupt in regard of their constitution, doctrine, worship, ministery, that if men beleeve and walke according thereunto, they cannot be saved.

div.head: Q. And may not thus much befall a true church?
div.p: A. No; a true Church is either pure in these things, or if corrupt, yet not so corrupt as to overthrow salvation.

div.head: CHAP. 30. Of the power or liberty of churches, and of church officers.
Q. WHat is the power or liberty of particular Churches?
div.p:
A. It is not civill or worldly, for Christs kingdome is not of this world Iohn 18. 36.; neither is it independent and supreame, for that belongs only
to Christ Matth. 28. 18. Iam. 4. 12.; but their power is Spirituall and ministeriall.

div.head: Q. And wherein have they such power?
div.p: A. They have such power from Christ to exercise all the Ordinances of true Religion, and to assemble together for the exercise thereof; and in particular to choose Officers to themselves, and to practice Discipline or censures.

div.head: Q. Whether have Churches absolute power from Christ to assemble together for the exercise of true Religion, or onely so far forth as the Princes of the earth shall give them leave?
div.p: A. Princes ought not to hinder these things, but to be nursing fathers to the Church Ezra 6. 8, 11, 12▪ Isai 49. 23.; and it is a great blessing of God when they are such Ezra 7. 27..

div.head: Q. But if Princes be not such, what ought the Church to do in such case?
div.p: A. They must not neglect to observe the commandements of God, for lack of the commandement of man Mat. 28. 20. Acts 1. 15. & 21. 42. & 5. 12. & 6. 1, 2., because Jesus Christ who giveth them commandement for these things, is the King of Kings, and the Prince of the Kings of the earth Rev. 17. 14. & 1. 5..

div.head: Q. To whom belongeth the power of choosing Officers to the Church?
div.p: A. The Church is to choose her own Officers, Acts 1. 23. & 6. 3, 5. & 14. 23.

div.head: Q. How may that be further cleared?
div.p: A. Either the Church must choose her own Officers, or else men may intrude themselves; or Officers must be called immediately of God, or be appointed by some other men: none of which may be affirmed.

div.head: Q. Why may not men intrude themselves?
div.p: A. No man must take this honour to himself to be an Officer in the Church, but he that is called of God, as was Aaron, Heb. 5. 4.

div.head: Q. And why may not a man be called of God immediately?
div.p: A. Such kind of callings are not to be expected in these daies, as being particular to Apostles and other extraordinary Officers, Gal. 1. 1.

div.head: Q. But why may no other men appoint Officers to the Church?
div.p: A. Other men that are not of the Church have no such authority given them as to appoint Offices to the Church.

div.head: Q. If men must not be Officers without a calling, and immediate callings be ceased, and other men may not appoint Church Officers, it remaineth then that the Church is to choose her own Officers: but unto what Functions must the Church choose Officers?
div.p:
A. Onely to such Functions as are appointed by Christ in his word Mat. 21. 25. and are of ordinary
and perpetuall use in the Church; for otherwise they cannot expect that God will be with them in the choise, or blesse the officers unto them.

div.head: Q. VVhat are the Officers appointed by Christ for ordinary and perpetuall use in the Church?
div.p: A. They are Bishops and Deacons Phil. 1. 1. 1 Tim. 3. 1, 8., which Bishops are also called Elders 1 Tim 5. 17. Acts 20. 17, 28. 1 Pet. 5. 1, 2, 3. more particularly, they are Pastors, Teachers Eph. 4. 11., ruling Elders 1 Tim. 5. 17., Deacons 1 Tim. 3. 8., and Widdows 1 Tim. 5. 3, 9..

div.head: Q. What are Pastors?
div.p: A. They are Elders of the Chuch, who are to quicken the hearts of the people unto all faith and obedience, and to reprove and comfort where there is need, by attending upon Exhortation Rom. 12. 8. 1 Cor. 12 8., with a word of wisdom.

div.head: Q. What are Teachers?
div.p: A. They are Elders of the Church who are to instruct the people in the good knowledge of the Lord, and to refute errour Tit. 1. 9. by attending upon teaching sound doctrine with a word of knowledge Rom. 12 7. 1 Cor. 12. 8..

div.head: Q. What are ruling Elders?
div.p:
A. They are Elders of the Church, who though they doe not labour in the word and
doctrine 1 Tim. 5. 17., yet they are to guide the Church in comelinesse and order, and peaceably attending upon ruling with diligence Mat. 26. 5. & 27. 1. Luke 22. 66. 1 Cor. 12. 28. Rom. 12. 8. 1 Tim. 5. 17..

div.head: Q. VVhat are Deacons?
div.p: A. They are Officers of the Church, who are to retaine, preserve, and distribute Acts 4. 35. & 6. 2, 3. 2 Chron. 26. 20. & 2 Chron. 31. 14. Neh. 11. 16. the outward Treasures of the Church, for the reliefe of the poore, and other outward affaires of the Church, in simplicity and faithfulnesse Rom. 12. 8. Neh. 13. 13..

div.head: Q. VVhat are widows and their works?
div.p: A. They are godly and ancient women, left desolate and destitute of outward succour, who are to attend the sick, and such like offices as are more suitable to be performed by women then by men, 1 Tim. 5. 9, 10. Rom. 16. 1.

div.head: Q. What persons must the Church choose for these Offices?
div.p: A. Such members of the Church Ezek. 33. 2. Acts 6. 3., as by sufficient experience, time, and triall 1 Tim. 3. 10. & 5. 22,, are known to be fitted with gifts 1 Tim. 3. 2, &c. Titus 1. 5, 6, &c. 1 Kings 12. 31. & 13. 33. and graces from God for the places that the Church would put them in.

div.head: Q. How must Officers be put into their places?
div.p:
A. All of them by solemn prayer unto God,
and with imposition of hands upon Elders and Deacons, and in the ordaining of Elders with fasting also. Acts 6. 6. 1 Tim. 4. 14. & 5. 22. Heb. 6. 2. Acts 14. 26.

div.head: CHAP. 31. Of Church Discipline or Censures.
Q. WHat is Church Discipline?
div.p: A. A personall application of the will of God by censures, for the preventing and removing of scandals.

div.head: Q. What are the parts of it?
div.p: A. Binding and loosing Mat. 16. 19 & 18. 8., which may be also called retaining and remitting of sinnes Iohn 20. 23.; and the former is either Admonition 1 Thess. 5 14. 2 Thess. 3. 15. or Excommunication Mat. 18. 17. 1 Cor. 15. 5..

div.head: Q. What persons are subject to Church-censures?
div.p: A. All and onely they that are member of the Church, Mat. 18. 15. 1 Cor. 5. 12. Psa. 149. 4.

div.head: Q. In what way, and by what steps and degrees must an offending brother be dealt withall?
div.p: A. If the matter be private, I must first reprove him privately; if this doe not win him, I must then take one or two more, Matth. 18. 15. 16.

div.head: Q. How if this also prevaile not?
div.p:
A. Then the matter must be told unto the Church, and the Church must publiquely admonish
him; and if he do not heare the Church, he is to be excommunicated, Mat. 18. 17.

div.head: Q. In what manner must admonition or reproof, whether private or publique, be administred?
div.p: A. Sometimes with meeknesse Gal. 6. 1., and sometimes with severity and sharpnesse 1 Cor 4. 21. 2 Cor. 13. 2. Gal. 3. 1., according to the condition of the person sinning, the sinne committed, and the manner of doing Iude 22. 23. Num. 12. 9, 10, 14..

div.head: Q. How else?
div.p: A. Alwaies with due solemnity, as an ordinance of God Mat. 18. 15, &c. , in the Name of Christ, and so that the winning Lev. 19. 17. Gal. 6. 1. Mat. 18. 15, 16. of the party must be the thing that must be aymed at.

div.head: Q. VVhat is Excommunication?
div.p: A. A putting away, or cutting off from the communion and fellowship of the Church, 1 Cor. 5. 2, 13. Gal. 5. 12. Mat. 18. 17.

div.head: Q. For what sinnes must men be excommunicated?
div.p: A. For hainous and flagitious k offences being publiquely known, and for other offences persisted in with obstinacy after due admonition Mal. 18. 17.. 1 Cor. 5. 1, 4, 5.

div.head: Q. For what end should men be excommunicated?
div.p:
A. For the healing of the offendor 1 Cor. 5. 5. 1 Tim. 1. 20., and for the preserving others from sinne Deut. 17. 13. 1 Tim. 5. 20. 1 Cor. 5. 6, 7., and for
the glory of the Name of God which is blasphemed because of the sinne of Church-members 2 Sam. 12. 14. Rom. 2. 24.

div.head: Q. How should a man behave himselfe towards them that are excommunicated?
div.p: A. He must avoyd all Church-communion with them Matth. 18. 17., and all voluntary civill fellowship 1 Cor. 5. 11. 2 Thes. 3. 14., that may argue approbation or familiarity: But not such duties as men are bound unto in naturall or civill respects r Iohn 18. 36..

div.head: Q. When must a man under censure be loosed and forgiven?
div.p: A. When he gives such signes of repentance as may satisfie rationall charity that the sinne is truly subdued and mortified, Luke 17. 3, 4. 1 Cor. 5. 5. 2 Cor. 2. 6, 7, 8.

div.head: CHAP. 32. Of the life that beievers ought to live in the world, and of the Law of God.
Q. WHat ought to be the life of them that are in Christ?
div.p: A. A course of holy obedience, and service to God all the daies of their life, Luke 1. 74, 75. 1 Pet. 1. 14, 15, 16, 17. Tit. 3. 8. Eph. 2. 10.

div.head: Q. VVhat is the generall rule of obedience?
div.p:
A. Not the commandements of men Hos. 5. 11. Col. 2. 22., nor that which is good in our own eyes Deut. 12. 8., but that
will of God which is therefore revealed unto us that we might do it Mat. 6. 10. & 26. 39, 42. Ephes. 6. 6, 7. Deut. 29. 29. Micah 6. 8.

div.head: Q. VVhether may not unbelievers perform duties of obedience?
div.p: A. They may performe many things which are good for the matter of them Isai 58. 2. Mat. 6. 1, 2, 5. & 23. 2, 4, 5., but not so as to please God in any thing they doe Heb. 11. 6. Mat. 7. 18. Iohn 15. 5..

div.head: Q. If they cannot please God in any thing they doe, had they not best then to neglect goods duties altogether?
div.p: A. Not so: for they are nowhere exempted from the commandement.

div.head: Q. Are believers able to performe obedience to God?
div.p: A. They are able by the power of Christ that strengthens them, to doe the will of God in some measure of truth, as being now alive from the dead, and created in Christ Jesus to good works, Phil. 4 13. Eph. 2. 10. Rom. 6. 11.

div.head: Q. But can they doe this in such perfection as the Law of God requireth?
div.p: A. No, in no wise Exod. 28. 38. Neb. 13. 22. Isai 64. 6., and the reason is because they know but in part 1 Gor. 13. 9, 12., and have flesh dwelling in them, and lusting against the Spirit Gal. 5. 17. Rom. 7. 14. 21, 23..

div.head: Q. Should they not then omit good duties altogether, seeing they cannot perform them in that perfection which the Law requireth?
div.p: A. Not so, but doe them in uprightnesse of heart, as God shall inable them Mat. 5. 16. Col. 1. 10., because God of his mercy through Christ hath promised to pardon their infirmities and sinnes, and to accept their sincere, though weake endeavours Mal. 3. 17. 2 Cor. 8. 12. Num. 23. 21..

div.head: Q. VVhat is the speciall rule according to which the life of a christian ought to be framed?
div.p: A. The life of a christian ought to be framed according to the morrall Law of God, Rom. 13. 8, 9. Eph 6 2, 3 Iam 2 8.

div.head: Q. How may that be further cleared?
div.p: A. Because christians are not set at liberty to sinne Rom. 6. 1, 15., and no man knoweth what is sinne but by the Law Rom. 7. 7. & 3 20. 1 Iohn 3. 4..

div.head: Q. How else?
div.p: A. Because in the new covenant God doth not promise to take away the Law, but to write it in our hearts Ier. 31 33. Ezek. 26. 37..

div.head: Q. VVhat rules are to be observed for our better understanding the commandements of the Law?
div.p: A. Every commandement of the Law is spirituall. reaching not onely to the outward man, but also to the heart, soule, and conscience, Rom. 7. 14. Mat. 5. 22, 28.

div.head: Q. What is another rule?
div.p: A. Under the negative part the affirmative is comprehended, and under the affirmative the negative, Mark 3. 4. Psal. 34. 14.

div.head: Q. What may be a third rule for the same purpose?
div.p: A. Under one vice forbidden, all of the same kind are forbidden also; with all the causes, occasions, and signes thereof. And under one duty are commanded all of the same kind, with all the means and helps thereof.

div.head: Q. VVhat may be a fourth rule?
div.p: A. God requireth not only that we keep the Law our selves, but that as much as is in us we cause others to keep it also.

div.head: Q. How many are the commandements of the Law?
div.p: A. In respect of the generall heads they are ten Deut. 4. 13. & 10. 4.; but all may be referred to two kinds: duties to God in the foure first Commandements, and duties to our neighbour in the six latter.

div.head: Q. VVhat is the main scope of the first commandement, Thou shalt have no other Gods before me?
div.p: A. Here is required all that naturall worship of God, whether the same be inward or outward, which is such as if there were no Law prescribed, yet if we well know his nature, we would undoubtedly perform it to him.

div.head: Q. Name some principall duties that are here required, with the contrary vices forbidden?
div.p: A. Here is required faith in God 2 Chro. 20. 20. Psal. 27. 1. 3. and 37. 3. 5., love to his Majesty Deut. 6 5. Mat. 10. 37., and hope in him Lam. 3. 23, 26. Ier. 17. 13. Psal. 78. 7., hearing his voice Ier 13. 15. Isay 58. 2. Acts 16. 14., calling upon him by prayer Psal. 50. 15. and 32. 6. and 65. 2. Phil. 4. 6., and such like.

div.head: Q. And what are the evils forbidden in this first commandement?
div.p: A. Here is forbidden Atheisme Psal. 14. 1. Titus 1. 16., Ignorance of God Psa. 79. 6. Ier. 10. 25. Iohn 8. 19., unbeliefe Isay 7. 9. Heb. 10. 38. Ier. 17. 5, 6., dispaire Gen. 4. 13. Mat. 27. 3, 4. 5., pride Acts 12. 23. Dan. 4. 29. 30. and 5. 20., hatered Rom. 1. 30. Psal. 139. 21., and contempt of God Exod. 5. 2. Psal. 10. 13., and all inordinate setting of our hearts upon any creature Ier. 17. 5. Math. 10. 37. Eph. 5. 5. Phil. 3. 19.,

div.head: Q What is the maine scope of the second commandement?
div.p: A. The second commandement enjoyneth all that worship of God which is by divine Institution and ordinance Mat. 28. 20. Deut. 12. 32.

div.head: Q What are some of the particulars?
div.p:
A. The publike and solemne preaching and hearing of his word Deut. 33. 10. Acts 15. 21. Luke 4. 15, 16., and prayer 1 Tim. 2. 1, 2. Acts. 3. 1. and 16. 13. Luke 1. 10., celebration of Sacraments Mat. 3. 1, 6. and 26. 26. &c., Church, fellowship Acts 2. 42. and 9. 26., election
and ordaining of ministers and their whole ministration Acts 14. 23. and 6. 2, 3. &c. , with the due observation of Church discipline Mat. 18. 15 &c. 1 Cor. 5. 4, 5.,

div.head: Q. What is the evill here forbidden?
div.p: A. All neglect of the instituted worship of God Mat. 28. 20 Deut. 12. 32. Zech. 14. 16, 17, 18, 19. Luke 14. 18, 19, and all worshipping of him after the Images, Imaginations or Inventions of men Exod. 20. 4. 5. Num. 15. 39. 1 Kings 12, 31, 32, 33. and 13. 33. Mat. 15. 9. Col. 2. 20, 21, 22, 23.

div.head: Q. What is the sum of the third commandement?
div.p: A. The things here required are the due manner of observing and using all things that pertaine to the naturall or instituted worship of God, and all that name of God whereby he makes himselfe knowne unto his people?

div.head: Q. Shew it by some instances?
div.p: A. Here is required preparations to Gods service Eccl. 5. 1. Psal. 26. 2. Exod. 19. 10, 11, 14, 15, Reverence Heb. 12. 28, 29. Psal. 5. 7., devotion 1 Chro. 29. 9. Isay 58. 13 Luke 2. 37., sincerity Rom. 1. 9. Iohn 423. 24▪ 2 Tim. 2. 22., fruitfulnesse under ordinances Luke 13. 6. Mat. 21. 34., comlinesse 1 Cor. 24. 40. 1 Cor. 11. 13., or der 1 Cor. 14. 29, 30, 31, 33, 40., and such like.

div.head: Q. What is the evill forbidden in the third commandement?
div.p: A. All rash vaine and light using of the titles Deut. 28. 58., word Psa. 138. 2. Isay 66. 2, 5., and ordinances of the Lord 1 Chron 15 13., as sleeping at sermons Acts 20. 9. or at prayer, and wandering thoughts at the same mat. 15. 8. Ezek. 33 31, all confusions in Church meeting 1 Cor. 14. 33., and all using of any thing that is called Gods name, otherwise then it ought to be used Mal. 1. 1, 6, 7, 12, 14.

div.head: Q. What is the summe of the fourth commandement?
div.p: A. The consecrating and observing of that seventh part of time in Gods solemne worship which he hath instituted and ordayned, which is the holy keeping of the Sabbath Isay 58. 13.

div.head: Q. What is the maine sinne here forbidden?
div.p: A. All holy dayes of mens devising without warrant of his word 1 King 12. 32, 33. Exod. 32. 5., and all profaining of the Lords holy time or any part of it Isay 58. 13. Exod. 16. 29. 30. and 34. 21. Neh. 13. 15, 16, 17. Ier. 17. 21. 22., by needlesse words, works, or thoughts.

div.head: Q VVhat is required in the fifth commandement?
div.p:
A. To maintaine and yeeld unto men that honour that is due unto them in respect of their places and degrees, whether they be naturall parents Lev. 19. 3. Eph. 6. 1, 2, 3., husbands Eph. 5. 22, 24., masters Eph. 6. 5, 6, 7, 8., magistrates Rom. 13. 1, 2. Tit. 3 1., ministers
1 Tim. 5. 17. 1 Thes. 5. 12, 13., aged persons Lev. 19. 32. Iob. 32. 4, 6., or any other superiours, or qualls, and inferior Rom. 12. 10. 1 Pet. 2. 17.

div.head: Q. VVhat is the contrary evill here forbidden?
div.p: A. All such carriage as tends to the dishonour of our neighbours.

div.head: Q. VVhat is required in the sixth commandement?
div.p: A. Due care of the life and person of our neighbour the contrary whereof is murder Exod. 21. 12. Numb. 35. 20. 21, 30, 31.; fighting and quarrelling Tit. 3. 2., rash anger Mat. 5. 22. Eph. 4. 26, 27., malice, hatred Tit. 3. 3., and envy Prov. 27. 4. Acts 7. 9., and such like.

div.head: Q. VVhat is the summe of the seventh commandement?
div.p: A. Due care of chastity and purity from all the lusts of uncleannesse.

div.head: Q. Instance in some of the sinnes here forbidden?
div.p: A. Here is forbidden all unchast thoughts and lust of the heart Mat. 5. 28. Col. 3. 5., filthy dreames Deut. 23. 10. Iude 8., lookes Math. 5. 28. 2 Pet 2. 14. Gen. 39. 7., speeches 1 Cor. 15. 33. Eph. 4. 29. and 5. 4., and apparrell Pro. 7. 10. 1 Tim. 2. 9, 10. Eph. 1. 8., gestures of dalliance Pro. 7. 13. Gen. 26. 8., actions of Sodomie Lev. 20. 13. Rom. 1. 26, 27., bestiality Lev. 20. 15, 16., selfe polution Gen. 38. 9. 1 Cor. 6. 9., adultery Lev. 20. 10., fornication 1 Cor. 6. 13, 18., and wantonnesse Gal. 5. 19. Eph. 4. 19.,

div.head: Q. VVhat is the summe of the Eight commandement?
div.p: A. Due care of our neighbours outward estate whether it be lands, houses, cattell, corne, or ought else.

div.head: Q. Name some of the sins forbidden in this commandement?
div.p: A. Here is forbidden all neglect or hindrance of our neighbours outward estate, whether it be by idlenesse Gen. 3. 19. 2 Thes. 3. 10, 11., covetousnesse Heb. 13. 5. Eph. 5. 3. 1 Tim. 6. 9, 10., non payment of debts Psal. 37. 21. 2 Kings 6. 5. Rom. 13. 8., oppression Lev. 15. 14, 17. Amos 8. 5., by excessive prices or wages, Robbery Lev. 19. 13. Pro. 22. 22. Ezek. 18. 10. & 33 15., Theevery Eph. 4. 28. Zech. 5. 3, 4., or deceit 1 Thes. 4. 6. Lev. 19, 35, 36.,

div.head: Q VVhat is the summe of the ninth commandement?
div.p: A. Truth in speeches, promises and our dealings amongst men; and the contrary forbidden is all lying and false speaking, Eph. 4. 25. Col. 3. 9, 10 Psal. 15, 2. Micah 6. 12. Psa. 12. 2.

div.head: Q What is the summe of the tenth commandement?
div.p: A. Contentment with out owne outward estate Heb. 13 5 Phil. 4. 11. 1 Tim. 6. 6., and not to covet that which is our neighbours 1 Kings 21. 2, 4. Rom. 7 7., but hartily to desire and rejoyce in his good, as well as in our own Rom 12. 15. Iob. 31. 29.,

div.head: CHAP 33. Of the Death and Resurrection of the body, and the last judgement.
Q WHat is to be believed concerning death?
div.p:
A. It is now appointed of God, that Adam and all his children must die Heb. 9 27. Psal. 89. 48., except Enoch
Heb. 11. 5. and Elias 2. Kings 2. 11▪ , and such as shall be found alive at the comming of Christ to judgement 1 Cor. 15. 51, 52..

div.head: Q Why hath God so appointed?
div.p: A. Because of sinne Gen. 2. 17. & 3. 29. Rom. 5. 12. 1 Cor. 15. 21, 22., for if sinne had not entered into the world, there had never been death.

div.head: Q. But why should believers die, seeing Christ hath suffered death for them, and so hath taken away all punishment of sinne?
div.p: A. They die not now in way of punishment for their sinne properly, but for other ends and repects.

div.head: Q. For what ends doe they die?
div.p:
A. That they may be freed from all the
evils of this life Isai 57. 1. Revel. 14. 13., and be brought to rest and glory with Christ Phil. 1. 23. Isai 57. 2. Iohn 14. 3..

div.head: Q. What is the state of the godly immediately upon their death?
div.p: A. Their bodies doe sleep in the grave, as in the bed of spices Isai 57. 2. Rev. 14. 13., and their soules which are immortall are made glorious in the presence of God in Heaven Eccl. 12. 7. Phil. 1. 23. 2 Cor. 5. 1, 8. Luke 23. 34. Acts 7. 59..

div.head: Q And what is the state of the wicked upon their death?
div.p: A. Their bodies lie rotting in the grave, through the heavy curse of God Gen. 3. 12. Psal. 49. 14.; and their soules are tormented in hell, in unspeakable woe and misery Luke 16. 23..

div.head: Q. Shall the bodies of men lie for ever in the grave, and never be united to their soules again?
div.p: A. Not so, for there will be a resurrection of the just and unjust Acts 24. 15., and all that are in the graves shall come forth Iohn 5. 28, 29..

div.head: Q. In what manner shall the bodies of the Saints arise?
div.p: A. For substance the same bodies that they were at death 1 Cor. 15. 53. Iob 19. 26, 27.; but for quality greatly changed Phil. 2. 21., insomuch that they shall be raised incorruptible, glorious, powerfull, and spirituall 1 Cor. 15. 42, 43, 44..

div.head: Q. VVhat great matter is it for godly men to rise again, seeing wicked men shall rise also?
div.p: A. They shall not rise by vertue of any union with Christ as their head, as the godly shall Rom. 8. 11. 2 Cor. 4. 14. 1 Thes. 4. 14.; but onely by the power of Christ, as their Judge Iohn 5. 28..

div.head: Q. VVherein else doth the resurrection of the godly and wicked differ?
div.p: A. The wicked shall not rise in such a glorious and excellent manner, nor unto the same end with the godly, but to the resurrection of damnation, Iohn 5. 29.

div.head: Q. What followeth after the Resurrection?
div.p: A. The eternall judgement, Heb. 6. 2. & 9. 27.

div.head: Q. When will the day of judgement be?
div.p: A. It is certainly appointed and decreed of God when it shall be Acts 17. 31.; but it is not known to us that we might alwaies live in watchfulnesse Mark 13 32, 33.

div.head: Q. Who must be judge at that day?
div.p: A. Jesus Christ is appointed of God to be the Judge of quick and dead. Acts 10. 42. & 17. 31. Iohn 5. 22, 27. 2 Tim. 4. 1. 2 Cor. 5. 10.

div.head: Q. Who must be judged?
div.p: A. All the world, both living and dead; and this of all things done in this life, whether they be good or evil. Acts 17, 31. 2 Cor. 5. 10. 2 Tim. 4. 1. 1 Pet. 4. 5.

div.head: Q. In what manner will be come?
div.p: A. He will come suddenly 2 Pet. 3. 10. 1 Thes. 5, 2, 3., visibly Acts 1. 11. Luke 21. 27. Rev. 1. 7., and in wonderfull Majesty and glory Luke 21. 27. Tit. 2. 13, in flaming fire 2 Thes. 1. 8. 2 Pet. 3. 10, 12., with the voyce of the Archangell 1 Thess. 4. 16., and thousand thousands of Angels 2 Thess. 1. 7. Iude 14. Mat. 25. 31..

div.head: Q. What sentence will he give?
div.p: A. To them upon his right hand he will say, come ye blessed of my Father, inherit the Kingdome prepared for you from the foundation of the would. Matth. 25. 34.

div.head: Q. And what will be his sentence upon the wicked at his left hand?
div.p: A. To them upon his left hand he will say, Goe ye cursed into everlasting fire, prepared for the Divel and his Angels, Matth. 25. 41.

div.head: Q. What shall follow the pronouncing of the sentence?
div.p: A. The sentence pronounced shall presently be put in execution, so that every man shall receive according to his works. Matth. 25. 46. 2 Cor. 5. 10. Mat. 16. 27.

div.head: Q. What shall the wicked receive?
div.p:
A. They shall be punished with everlasting perdition from the presence of the Lord, and from the glory of his power 2 Thes. 1. 9., with the divell and his Angels Mat. 25. 41., in the lake that burneth with
Fire and Brimstone, which is the second death Rev. 21. 1. Mark 9. 43, 44.,

div.head: Q. And what shall the godly receive?
div.p: A. They shall have redemption and deliverance from all kind of evil Luke 21. 28. Eph. 4. 30. Rom. 8. 23..

div.head: Q. And what good shall they enjoy?
div.p: A. Wonderfull Psal. 31. 19., unspeakable and unconceivable 1 Cor. 2. 2. 2 Cor. 12. 4., and everlasting 2 Cor. 4. 17. Mat. 25. 46. 1 Pet. 1. 4. happinesse and glory in the highest heavens 2 Cor. 5. 1. Iohn 14. 2, 3. Heb. 11. 10., in the presence of God 1 Thes 4. 17., in whose presence is fulnesse of joy, and at whose right hand are pleasures for evermore Psal. 16. 11..
